revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Paul Boesch | image = Paul Boesch.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Paul Max Boesch | birth_date = {{birth date|mf=yes|1912|10|12}} | birth_place = [[Brooklyn]], [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|mf=yes|1989|3|7|1912|10|12}} | death_place = [[Sugar Land, Texas|Sugar Land]], [[Texas]], U.S. | death_cause = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = | years_active = | height = | weight = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = | module = {{Infobox professional wrestler|child=yes |names= |height= |weight= |billed= |trainer= |debut=1938 (as wrestler)
1947 (as announcer)
1966 (as promoter) |retired=1987 }} | module2 = {{Infobox military person |embed=yes |placeofburial= |placeofburial_label= |image= |caption= |nickname= |allegiance= {{Flag|United States of America|1912|size=23px}} |branch=[[File:Seal of the United States Department of War.png|25px]] [[United States Army]] |serviceyears= 1942-1945 |rank= |commands= |unit= |battles=[[World War II]]
[[Battle of Hürtgen Forest]] |awards={{ribbon devices|number=0|name=Combat Infantry Badge|width=25}} [[Combat Infantry Badge]]
{{ribbon devices|name=Silver Star ribbon|width=23}}  [[Silver Star]] and cluster
{{ribbon devices|name=Bronze Star ribbon|width=23}}  [[Bronze Star Medal]] and cluster
{{ribbon devices|ribbon=Purple Heart ribbon.svg|width=23}} [[Purple Heart|Purple Heart Medal]]
{{Ribbon devices|number=0|type=service-star|ribbon=United States Army and U.S. Air Force Presidential Unit Citation ribbon.svg|width=23}} [[Presidential Unit Citation (United States)|Distinguished Unit Citation]]
{{ribbon devices|type=service-star|name=Croix de Guerre 1939-1945 ribbon|width=23}} [[Croix de guerre 1939–1945 (France)|Croix de guerre]] with star (France) |relations= |laterwork= Professional wrestler, professional wrestling announcer and promoter }} }} '''Paul Max Boesch'''[http://www.familytreelegends.com/records/33861?c=search&first=paul&last=boesch Texas Deaths, 1964-1998] (October 2, 1912{{spaced ndash}}March 7, 1989) was a [[professional wrestler]] and promoter, most famous for his work as an announcer and promoter for [[Houston Wrestling]]. He also spent several stints working with the [[Universal Wrestling Federation (Bill Watts)|Universal Wrestling Federation]], [[World Class Championship Wrestling]], Jim Crockett Promotions, and the [[World Wrestling Entertainment|World Wrestling Federation]]. ==Early life and education== Boesch was born in [[Brooklyn|Brooklyn, New York]], on October 2, 1912. His family eventually moved from Brooklyn to nearby [[Long Beach, New York|Long Beach]], where Boesch graduated from [[Long Beach High School (New York)|Long Beach High School]] in 1929. A gifted athlete, he became a lifeguard at the [[Long Island]] beaches near his home, and he was skilled enough as a swimmer to place third in the North Atlantic Coast Lifeguard Competition in 1932. Boesch began wrestling professionally during the 1930s. His first notable match was a 90-minute bout against Pat Meehan in [[Calgary]] on November 25, 1938 that ended in a draw. ==Military Service== With the outbreak of [[World War II]], Boesch suspended his wrestling career to enlist in the [[United States Army]]. He graduated from [[officer candidate school]] in 1942 and earned a commission in the [[121st Infantry Regiment (United States)|121st Infantry Regiment]] of the [[8th Infantry Division (United States)|8th Infantry Division]]. Boesch deployed to Europe with his unit after the [[D-Day]] landings to take part in the offensive against [[Nazi Germany]]. As [[commanding officer]] of Company G, [[first lieutenant|1st Lt.]] Boesch led his [[company (military unit)|rifle company]] in one of the bloodiest and most desperate battles of the war on the [[Western Front (World War II)|Western Front]], the [[Battle of Hürtgen Forest]]. His unit took heavy casualties during the fighting, and Boesch himself was seriously injured by a German artillery shell. For his service, Boesch was awarded numerous decorations, including the [[Purple Heart]], the [[Silver Star|Silver Star with oak leaf clusters]], the [[Bronze Star|Bronze Star with oak leaf clusters]], and the [[Croix de guerre 1939–1945 (France)|French Croix de Guerre with star]]. He also earned the prized [[Combat Infantryman Badge]] and the [[Distinguished Unit Citation]], awarded to the soldiers of the 121st Infantry for their meritorious efforts in the Hürtgen Forest. After the war, he was honored with a Distinguished Citizens Award from the 121st Infantry Association for his outstanding community service with charitable groups including the [[Boys & Girls Clubs of America|Boys Club of America]]. Boesch authored a well-regarded memoir of his experiences in World War II entitled, ''Road to Huertgen: Forest in Hell''. ==Houston Wrestling== After World War II, Boesch returned to wrestling, competing in matches across North America. In 1947 he was injured in a car accident, forcing him to retire from competition. It was at this time that [[Houston Wrestling]] promoter Morris Sigel approached him to work for his growing Texas organization. Boesch became an advisor to Sigel as well as a radio announcer, and two years later became the promotion's first television commentator when the show debuted on local television. Boesch's wrestling broadcasts remained a fixture on Houston television for over 30 years, airing on station KHTV channel 39 (now [[KIAH]], a [[CW Network]] affiliate). After Sigel died in 1966, Boesch bought out Houston Wrestling from Sigel's widow. Boesch had essentially been training for this opportunity for 20 years, and he quickly brought the organization to new levels of success and visibility. Under Boesch’s leadership, Houston Wrestling quickly attained gained a reputation as one of the top regional wrestling promotions of its time. Promoters such as [[Gary Hart (wrestler)|Gary Hart]] ([[World Class Championship Wrestling]]) and wrestlers such as [[Barry Darsow]] would repeatedly praise Boesch's acumen and honesty as a promoter and businessman. Boesch is also credited with the invention of [[mud wrestling]], a concept he devised for a major match between [[Gus Sonnenberg]] and [[Harnam Singh]] in [[Seattle, Washington]]. Together with his nephew Peter Birkholz, Boesch entered Houston Wrestling into affiliations with [[Mid South Wrestling]], [[World Wrestling Entertainment|World Wrestling Federation]], [[Universal Wrestling Federation (Bill Watts)|Universal Wrestling Federation]], and [[World Class Championship Wrestling]] to ensure that top talent from all over the country would appear on his weekly Friday Night shows. As professional wrestling became a major entertainment business in the 1980s, most of Boesch's affiliates joined the [[National Wrestling Alliance]]. Boesch eventually shut down Houston Wrestling in favor of signing with [[Vince McMahon]] and the World Wrestling Federation, an affiliation that lasted only four months. After 55 years of working in the industry as a wrestler, announcer, and promoter, Paul Boesch retired on August 28, 1987 due to health concerns. The now-WWE hosted the Paul Boesch Retirement Show in Houston in his honor, which drew a sell-out crowd to the [[Sam Houston Coliseum]]. During the show, personal friend and then-[[Vice President]] [[George H. W. Bush|George Bush]] had a telegram delivered praising Boesch for his lifelong commitment to service. ==Death== Boesch died on March 7, 1989 after suffering a [[heart attack]] in [[Sugar Land, Texas]]. He was inducted into the [[Wrestling Observer Newsletter Hall of Fame]] as a charter member in 1996. He was inducted into the [[Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame]] in 2005 as a non-wrestler participant in the business. ==Legacy== Paul Boesch's contribution to the wrestling industry has been praised by numerous observers as well as by former wrestlers themselves. [[World Wrestling Entertainment|WWE]] commentator [[Jim Ross]] has publicly stated that he believes Boesch is worthy of enshrinement in the [[WWE Hall of Fame]].{{cite web |url=http://www.jrsbarbq.com/blog/too-early-think-about-2009-wwe-hall-fame-fox-news-join-elitists-who-look-down-their-noses-wrest |title=Too Early to Think About the 2009 WWE Hall of Fame??.. Fox News Join Elitists Who Look Down Their Noses at Wrestling.. WWE Brand |author=Jim Ross |date=April 12, 2008 |work=J.R.'s Blog |publisher=JRsBarBQ.com |accessdate=}} The Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame states that "his influence in professional wrestling cannot be overestimated" due to his expansive promotion of the sport throughout Texas. Through his efforts, Boesch turned Houston into one of the top promotions on the regional wrestling circuit. In addition to his professional accomplishments, Boesch was active in numerous philanthropic endeavors throughout his life. He was a highly visible fixture in the community during his many years in Houston, serving in charitable organizations like the Boys Club and promoting the benefits and necessity of physical fitness for America's youth. To generations of Houstonians and Texans in general, Boesch was the face of professional wrestling. ==Bibliography== During his life, Boesch wrote four books: * ''Road to Huertgen: Forest in Hell'' (1962), his story as a soldier in World War II. * ''Much of Me in Each of These'' (1966), a book of poetry composed by Boesch himself. * ''The Career of Paul Boesch-- One Man, One Sport, One Lifetime-- 50 years on the mat'' (1981), an autobiography. * ''Hey Boy- Where'd You Get Them Ears?'' (2001), a secondary autobiography including his later memoirs. ==Awards and accomplishments== *'''[[National Wrestling Alliance]]''' **[[NWA Hall of Fame]] (Class of 2012){{cite web|url=http://www.f4wonline.com/more/more-top-stories/118-daily-updates/28434-sat-update-great-tv-show-wwe-multiple-releases-austin-talks-wwe-hall-of-fame-best-night-for-bellator-ppv-predictions-nwa-hall-of-fame-james-storm-headlines-benefit-show-devitt-takes-another-title|title=Sat. update: Great TV show, WWE multiple releases, Austin talks WWE Hall of Fame, Best night for Bellator, PPV predictions, NWA Hall of Fame, James Storm headlines benefit show, Devitt takes another title|last=Meltzer|first=Dave|authorlink=Dave Meltzer|date=2012-11-17|accessdate=2012-11-17|work=[[Dave Meltzer#Wrestling Observer Newsletter|Wrestling Observer Newsletter]]}} *'''''[[Pro Wrestling Illustrated]]''''' **[[PWI Stanley Weston Award|Editors' Award]] (1987){{cite web|url=http://www.pwi-online.com/pages/PWIawards.html|title=PWI Awards|work=[[Pro Wrestling Illustrated]]|publisher=[[Kappa Publishing Group]]|accessdate=June 8, 2017}} *'''''[[Wrestling Observer Newsletter]]''''' **[[Wrestling Observer Newsletter Hall of Fame]] (Class of 1996) *'''[[Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame and Museum]]''' **Class of 2005 ==Awards and decorations==

{{Other uses|Pearls before swine (disambiguation){{!}}Pearls before swine}} {{Original research|date=January 2015}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox Comic strip |title=Pearls Before Swine |image=File:Large pb rec 201804050954.jpg |creator=[[Stephan Pastis]] |current= |status=Running |syndicate=[[United Media|United Feature Syndicate]] (2001–2011)
[[Universal Uclick]] (2011–present) |publisher= [[Andrews McMeel Publishing]] |genre=Humor, [[Black comedy]], [[Gag-a-day]] |first=December 31, 2001 (''[[The Washington Post]]'')
January 7, 2002 |last= }} '''''Pearls Before Swine''''', (also known as '''''Pearls''''') is an American [[comic strip]] written and illustrated by [[Stephan Pastis]]. It chronicles the daily lives of five [[Anthropomorphism|anthropomorphic]] animals: a [[Pig]], a [[Rat]], a [[Zebra]], a [[Goat]], and a [[fraternity]] of [[crocodiles]], as well as a number of supporting characters. Each character represents an aspect of Pastis' own personality and world view.{{cite news| url = http://cartoonician.com/swine-connoisseur-the-stephan-pastis-interview/ |title=Swine Connoisseur: The Stephan Pastis Interview | work=[[Hogan's Alley (magazine)|Hogan's Alley]]| issue= 16| date= 2009| accessdate= June 10, 2014}} The daily and Sunday comic strip is distributed by [[Universal Uclick]] (by [[United Media]]'s United Feature Syndicate before 2011). The strip's style is most notable for its dark humor, breaking of the [[fourth wall]], mockery of other comic strips and stories concocted in elaborate fashion leading into a pun. == Publication history== Prior to creating ''Pearls Before Swine'', Pastis worked as a lawyer in California. Bored in his law school classes, Pastis started to doodle a rat, eventually casting it in a non-syndicated comic strip which he titled ''Rat''. The title character of Rat would later become one of the main characters in ''Pearls Before Swine''. Pastis continued to draw comics; the character Pig came from a failed strip titled ''The Infirm''. In 1999, Pastis first submitted ''Pearls Before Swine'' to syndicates. Several expressed interest and three accepted it,{{cite journal| title=Forum Interview with Stephan Pastis, Creator of Pearls Before Swine | year=2004| journal=Phi Kappa Phi Forum |volume=84|issue=3|pages=34–37| url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-121875458.html }}{{subscription required}} but they could not convince their sales staff that it was marketable. However, Amy Lago, an editor at [[United Media]], saw the strip's potential and launched it on the United Media website in November 2000, to see what kind of response it would generate. Pastis recalled in 2009, {{quote|United signed me in December 1999, and they put me in development ... where the syndicate says, OK, you were funny in your submission packet, but for all we know, it took you 10 years to come up with these 30 strips. So we want you to keep drawing, and we’ll watch you. If you’re good, we’ll agree to put you in newspapers. A development period can be anywhere from two weeks to a year. Not all cartoonists have to do it, but most do.}} ''Pearls Before Swine'' debuted in 2000 as a website strip under [[United Media|United Feature Syndicate]]. When [[Scott Adams]], creator of ''[[Dilbert]]'' and supporter of the strip, told his fans about ''Pearls Before Swine'', interest skyrocketed, and the strip was taken to print. Aiding Pastis in the artistic elements of the strip was [[Darby Conley]], creator of the comic strip ''[[Get Fuzzy]]''.{{cite book|last=Pastis|first=Steven|title=Pearls Before Swine: BLTs Taste So Darn Good|publisher=Andrews McMeel Publishing|year=2003|pages=7–8|isbn=0-7407-3437-7|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QlmCVygKub8C&dq=pearls+before+swine&source=gbs_summary_s&cad=0|accessdate=2008-09-27}} United Feature Syndicate launched the strip in newspapers on December 31, 2001 in ''[[The Washington Post]]''.Pastis, Stephan, ''Sgt. Piggy's Lonely Hearts Club Comic'' (Andrews McMeel Publishing, 2004; {{ISBN|0-7407-4807-6}}), p.5: "''Pearls'' was supposed to launch in newspapers on January 7, 2002. But just prior to the launch, the ''Washington Post'' bought the strip and wanted to start running it a week early. Thus, this week of strips [dated beginning 12/31] was quickly put together just for the ''Post'', and this [12/31] strip became the first ''Pearls'' strip, published in exactly one paper". On January 7, 2002, ''Pearls'' was running in approximately 150 papers.{{cite web |url=http://www.andrewsmcmeel.com/products/?isbn=0740738135 |title=''This Little Piggy Stayed Home'' (March 2004): "Product Detail" |publisher=Andrewsmcmeel.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927043246/http://www.andrewsmcmeel.com/products/?isbn=0740738135 |archivedate=September 27, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} Since 2011, the strip has been appearing in 750 newspapers worldwide.{{cite web|url=http://stephanpastis.wordpress.com/about/ |title=About Pearls Before Swine |publisher=Stephanpastis.wordpress.com |date= |accessdate=2014-09-14}}Dwyer, Ed. [https://www.saturdayeveningpost.com/2016/11/the-funny-papers/ "CULTURE: The Funny Papers: Newspapers may be in trouble, but the comic strip is alive and well — and flourishing online,"] ''Saturday Evening Post'' (November 7, 2016). ==Influences== ''Pearls''{{'}} style and humor are inspired by several comic strips, chiefly ''[[Peanuts]]'', ''Dilbert'', ''[[Calvin and Hobbes]]'', ''[[Bloom County]]'' and ''[[The Far Side]]''. Pastis has drawn tributes to these influences in his strip. When asked in an interview about whether his profession as an attorney inspired the humor in the comic, he said, "I was very unhappy as a lawyer, and humor is a reaction to and defense against unhappiness.... if you dislike what you’re doing to the extent that I did, it gives you the impetus to get out."{{cite web|author=in Attorney Career Success Stories |url=http://www.jdblissblog.com/2006/11/stephan_pastis_.html |title=Interview: Stephan Pastis: Attorney Turned Cartoonist |publisher=Jdblissblog.com |date=November 6, 2006 |accessdate=2011-09-06}} Cartoonist Darby Conley, creator of ''[[Get Fuzzy]]'', helped teach Pastis the technical aspects of cartooning.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2006/SHOWBIZ/books/05/03/pastis.pearls/index.html|title=A Rat, a Pig and Some Really Dumb Crocodiles: Stephan Pastis dives deep for his 'Pearls Before Swine' strip|last=Leopold|first=Todd|date=May 4, 2006|work=CNN}} The two remain friends, sometimes poking fun at each other in their strips. ==Characters== {{main article|List of Pearls Before Swine characters}} {{Original research|date=June 2009}} ===Rat=== Rat (debut: December 30, 2001) is a [[narcissism|narcissistic]], misanthropic [[rat]], the [[antihero]] of the comic strip. He frequently breaks the [[fourth wall]]. Rat is an insensitive character in the strip, whose interactions with others are typically sarcastic, condescending, self-centered, insulting and often violent. In particular, he will frequently berate his creator on the general quality of the strip. Often self-employed, most of his businesses involve either punishing or [[Fraud|defrauding]] people for their ignorance, much in the same vein as [[Dogbert]], though with darker humor. His political views are right-wing, especially in foreign policy. Rat's short stories, which are mostly extremely cynical reflections on life and love, make up several comic strips. Pastis has mentioned that the character of Rat is his "voice" and that he identifies himself with Rat more than any other character.{{cite web|url=http://www.crescentblues.com/8_9issue/int_pastis.shtml |title=Artist Interview: "Stephan Pastis: Animal Attitude" |publisher=Crescent Blues |date= |accessdate=2011-09-06}}{{cite web|url=http://www2.ljworld.com/news/2006/dec/24/strip_deals_wry_pearls_wisdom/?living |title=Strip deals wry Pearls of wisdom / LJWorld.com |publisher=.ljworld.com |date=December 24, 2006 |accessdate=2011-09-06}} ===Pig=== Pig (debut: December 30, 2001) is the character that receives the most abuse from Rat (though ironically, he is Rat's only friend). He is kind by nature, but extremely stupid. Pig's jokes generally involve his stupidity; Pastis once stated that Pig is easy to write for because he misunderstands everything said to him, and, once it is explained, he misunderstands the explanation. Pig has a habit of talking to inanimate objects such as food, stop lights, or bait. Pig's moody on-and-off girlfriend, Pigita, often misunderstands his ignorant statements and will often become violent toward him. Pig loves to eat, including pork products, making him a [[Cannibalism in humans|cannibal]], although he appears to misunderstand this. Unlike the other characters, Pig almost never uses mock profanity. ===Goat=== Goat (debut: January 18, 2002) is the intellectual of the strip, usually appearing whenever there is a small issue dealing with a character or a conflict to be mediated. Goat has a hard time dealing with both Pig's stupidity and Rat's cruelty and occasional ignorance. He is sometimes seen telling other characters about various philosophical, political, and [[social issues]], though usually the others do not care. Goat's real name is revealed as "Paris" in the September 21, 2007 strip; he claims "Goat" is his stage name. In early strips, Goat has a beard; he first appears without it in the March 31, 2004 strip. ===Zebra=== {{original research|section|date=January 2015}} Zebra (debut: February 4, 2002), also known as "zeeba neighba" (zebra neighbor) by the crocodiles, is a [[zebra]] who is often seen trying to patch up relations between his herd back home and its predators. Pastis has stated that the Zebra's only goal is to avoid being eaten by his inarticulate next-door neighbors, the crocodiles. Jokes involving Zebra usually involve his interactions with predators. Because Stephan Pastis was once unable to draw lions, these particular predators were not shown in the strip until May 31, 2007,{{Cite web|url=http://www.gocomics.com/pearlsbeforeswine/2007/05/31|title=Pearls Before Swine by Stephan Pastis for May 31, 2007|last=|first=|date=May 31, 2007|website=GoComics|access-date=}} when two of them moved next door to Zebra, on the opposite side from the crocodiles. Zebra's lion neighbors, however, are male lions, which do not hunt, and they awkwardly remain friends. Prior to their appearance, Zebra has been corresponding with the lions by mail. ===Guard Duck=== The Guard Duck is, as his name implies, is the "guard duck" for Pig and Rat's home. His first appearance was March 14, 2005,{{cite web|url=http://www.gocomics.com/pearlsbeforeswine/2005/03/14 |title=Pearls Before Swine Comic Strip, March 14, 2005 on |publisher=Gocomics.com |date=March 14, 2005 |accessdate=2011-09-06}} when Pig bought him instead of a more expensive guard dog for the house. Originally, Guard Duck was described as a violent duck with [[anger management]] problems, but he transformed into a deluded soldier who sees the world as his battlefield. He responds to neighborhood problems militaristically, often using excessive violence (usually with an [[Rocket-propelled grenade|RPG]], his usual weapon). In the treasury ''The Crass Menagerie'', Stephan Pastis remarks that the Guard Duck has become so popular that he's become a sixth main character (after Rat, Pig, Goat, Zebra, and the crocs).{{cite book|title=The Crass Menagerie|page=32}} ===Crocodiles=== The ZZE fraternity of crocodiles (whose name supposedly means "Zeta Zeta Epsilon" but actually means "Zeeba Zeeba Eata") is described by Pastis as "inept and inarticulate neighbors" of Zebra. They repeatedly attempt to kill and eat Zebra, but fail every time as a result of their stupidity. Each croc has very little regard for his fellow crocs' lives; dozens of crocs have died in their botched attempts to kill Zebra. They speak in a "language" called "Croc-ese": English with very bad grammar and pronunciation. According to Pastis, "Croc-ese" is not meant to imitate any accent.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2005/12/13/Floridian/Exactly_what_ees_that.shtml|title=Exactly what ees that zeeba-eating accent|last=Squires|first=Chase|date=December 13, 2005|website=Tampa Bay Times|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304132802/http://www.sptimes.com/2005/12/13/Floridian/Exactly_what_ees_that.shtml|archive-date=March 4, 2016|dead-url=|access-date=}} They are on poor terms with all five main characters (with the possible occasional exception of Rat). In addition to the fraternity of crocodiles, there is a separate family of crocodiles that live in the neighborhood and are also neighbors to Zebra. The family consists of Larry, his wife Patty, and their son Junior (originally named Billy). Larry is a typical croc similar to those in the fraternity: he is also characterized by his stupidity and his failure to kill Zebra. In contrast, both his wife and son are intelligent and do not speak "Croc-ese". Patty is a housewife with a [[Bob cut|bob haircut]]. She is often frustrated with her husband's insensitivity and stupidity and even responds with physical violence in many cases. Despite this, Patty is still shown to love her husband. Junior is the only child of his family. He is a vegetarian, and also loves his father. ===Stephan Pastis=== Stephan Pastis appears self-reflexively in the strip. He is often seen with Rat, who makes him the target of criticism about his artwork and jokes involving puns. His character has also expressed his hate of being an attorney, which was his former career. He is usually depicted wearing a baseball cap backward, a plain white T-shirt, and blue jeans. ===Snuffles=== Snuffles (also known as Mister Snuffles) is Zebra's cat. Originally, he was adopted by the crocodiles on September 30, 2007, to kill Zebra, but the plan backfired. He does not talk like the other characters, only saying "Meow" (but the other characters can understand what he says). However, he is still shown to have human-like intelligence. While he is always obedient and good-natured to Zebra, he can be violent to others. He often commits illegal or immoral acts, which range from [[Ticket resale|scalping tickets]] to hiding weapons of mass destruction. Snuffles is often seen with Guard Duck. ===Semi-regular characters=== *'''Jef the Cyclist''' - A parody of an arrogant cyclist. He is loosely based on [[Jef Mallett]], the creator of the comic strip ''[[Frazz]]''. *'''Andy''' - A chained-up dog who dreams of being unchained. His optimism contrasts with the darkness of the comic strip. *'''Farina''' - Pig's sister, a [[mysophobia|germaphobe]] who lives in a plastic bubble. She is Rat's ex-girlfriend. *'''Pigita''' - Pig's on-and-off girlfriend. *'''Neighbor Bob''' - Rat and Pig's next-door neighbor, with whom Rat frequently fights. *'''Vikings''' - Pig’s [[Viking]] figurines; instead of killing people and plundering villages like most Vikings (which they should be, according to Rat) they prefer to watch shows like ''[[The Oprah Winfrey Show]]'' and ''[[The Ellen Degeneres Show]]''. *'''Lemmings''' - A group of four (sometimes five) [[lemmings]] that always contemplate jumping off a cliff. This is based on a myth created by a 1950s [[Disney Nature]] film about lemmings. *'''Comic Strip Censor''' - A man who gets mad whenever a character (usually Rat or Pig) would say something close to being offensive. This character often allows Stephan to get away with making dirty jokes in the strip because "No newspaper editor wants to censor [it] and risk looking like [him]"{{cite book |last=Pastis |first=Stephan |page=153 |authorlink=Stephan Pastis |date=2015 |title=Pearls Gets Sacrificed}} *'''Staci Pastis''' - Stephan’s ex-wife. Stephan lives in a basket outside her house. *'''Max and Zach''' - Two [[lions]] that live next door to Zebra, but they won’t eat him because it’s the female lions that do the hunting. *'''Mr. Death''' - Rat and Pig’s [[grim reaper]] neighbor. His appearance confuses people that would think that he’s there to kill them, when he isn’t. *'''Chuckie''' - A non-anthropomorphic [[sheep]]. *'''Killer Whale''' - An unnamed [[killer whale]] that is also a very bad predator. *'''John and Jennifer''' - Two [[Pinniped|seals]] that the whale tries to eat. *'''Bombast Cable''' - Rat and Pig’s cable company, who Rat always has trouble with on the phone. *'''Gary''' - Owner of Joe’s Roastery, a [[coffee]] shop Rat on-and-off works at. *'''Jeffy''' - A character from ''[[The Family Circus]]'' that appears in ''Pearls'' every time the former strip is parodied. ==Setting== The strip is set in a fictional suburb in [[Albany, California]].{{Citation needed|date=April 2017}} Venues where the characters can be found include a brick wall, a beach, a curb, a bar, and a diner. ==Style== Artistically, ''Pearls'' is extremely simple. Pastis stated, "People say that they like my strip's simplicity, but I'm doing the best I can to just to get up to that level. I'm not dumbing the art down." ''Pearls'' is a [[meta-joke|meta-comic]] in that it often satirizes the comics medium, and its characters frequently break the [[fourth wall]]. Characters frequently communicate with the author or with characters from other strips. Some strips are based on the premise that the characters live in a comic strip: for example, the strip published on January 14, 2008, had "roof fish" sitting on top of the panel fishing for the characters, and other strips have had smeared [[newsprint]] or beer affect the appearance of the strip. ''Pearls'' will often also mock older strips, such as ''[[Cathy]]'' and ''[[The Family Circus]]''. The frequent comedic jabs at long-running comic strips has earned Pastis the disdain of many comic artists, which the author referenced in a storyline where the ''Pearls'' cast is not invited to the 75th-anniversary [[Fictional crossover|crossover]] party of ''[[Blondie (comic strip)|Blondie]]''.{{Cite web|url=http://www.gocomics.com/pearlsbeforeswine/2005/9/23|title=Pearls Before Swine by Stephan Pastis for Sep 23, 2005|last=|first=|date=September 23, 2005|website=GoComics|access-date=}} Pastis will often employ a [[shaggy dog story]], using a great amount of dialogue to spin an elaborate premise often resolved with a character's unforeseen death or near death. A variation known as a [[feghoot]] builds to an intentionally bad [[pun]] in the penultimate panel, with the final panel showing the cartoon version of Pastis as the target of criticism, hostility, or even physical violence from the characters, usually Rat. ''Pearls'' uses [[Black comedy|dark humor]], at times involving topics such as death, depression and human suffering. ==Other media== In an interview on ''[[The Big Idea with Donny Deutsch]]'' that aired on February 7, 2008, Pastis mentioned that he had been approached by producers about an animated TV series based on ''Pearls''. In 2009, a line of ''Pearls'' plush dolls was released by Aurora World, Inc.,{{cite web|author=info@auroragift.com |url=http://www.auroragift.com/new_web/product/product_010.php |title=Pearls Before Swine at Aurora |publisher=Auroragift.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-06}} featuring four characters (Rat, Pig, Zebra and Croc) from the comic, to which Pastis jokingly said he would use for reference when unsure how to draw the characters.{{cite web|last=Cavna |first=Michael |url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/comic-riffs/2009/03/plush_pearls_toys_yes--what_a.html |title=Plush 'Pearls' Toys? Indeed-What a Croc! |publisher=Voices.washingtonpost.com |date=March 25, 2009 |accessdate=2011-09-06}} On October 20, 2010, [[RingTales]] launched their series of animated ''Pearls'' strips on [[Babelgum]]. Pastis has since begun to release these cartoons on [[YouTube]]. ==Books== {{Main article|List of Pearls Before Swine books}} There are over a dozen ''Pearls Before Swine'' books, mostly strip collections and treasuries. ==Awards== Pastis won the [[National Cartoonists Society]]'s [[National Cartoonists Society Division Awards|Division Award]] for Best Newspaper Comic Strip for ''Pearls'' in 2003, 2006 and 2014.{{cite web |publisher=[[National Cartoonists Society]] |accessdate=2010-11-22 |url=http://www.reuben.org/?page_id=611#strip |title=Division awards }} He was also nominated for the award in 2002 and 2008.{{cite news |url = http://www.dallasnews.com/entertainment/books/20110404-pearls-before-swine-creator-stephan-pastis-to-visit-dallas-area.ece |title='Pearls Before Swine' creator Stephan Pastis to visit Dallas area |work=Dallas Morning News |date=April 4, 2011 |first=Caitlin|last=Johnson}} Pastis was one of the National Cartoonists Society's nominees for Cartoonist of The '''Sakura catalog''' is a [[Japan]]ese [[stamp catalog]] illustrated in colors.
'''The Japanese Stamp Catalog Illustrated in Colors''' ({{lang-ja|[[:ja:原色日本切手図鑑|原色日本切手図鑑]]}}) was first published in October 1967, with fuII-colored illustrations, which surprised the philatelic world since a colored stamp catalog had never been thought of. Regarded as the most reliable and popular publication in Japan, it goes through fifteen editions in 1979, and more than 4,500,000 copies have been released in all. This is the companion volume to the '''Japanese Stamp Specialized Catalog'''. The catalog, nicknamed '''Sakura Catalog''', has been in pocket-size (118 x 148 mm) for several years, but now it is printed in the size of B6 (128 x 182 mm) so that it may be printed through the multicolor rotary press to meet the increased circulation and to make the use of thinner paper possible. On the occasion that all the pages have to be newly composed for the enlarged size, the English version of [[Postage stamp|stamp]] names is added for the sake of foreign collectors, and many marks are adopted to help them understand how the stamps are classified here.<ref name="sakura83">SAKURA Catalog of Japanese Stamps, Illustrated in Colours 1983. 18th Edition. Edited and Published by the Japan Philatelic Society, Inc. 1982.09.05. The size of B6 (128 x 182 mm). 240 p. (原色日本切手図鑑1983年版1982年9月5日 第18版発行(c)編集・発行 財団法人日本郵趣協会(JPS)B6判240ページ).</ref>

({{lang-ja|在中国局}}) * Miscellaneous ({{lang-ja|その他の切手類}}) ** [[British Commonwealth Occupation Force|British Forces Occupation]] Issues ({{lang-ja|日本[[:ja:イギリス連邦占領軍|占領イギリス連邦軍]]切手}}) * “[[Manchukuo|Manchukuo]]” [[Puppet state|Puppet Government]] ({{lang-ja|[[:ja:満州国|「満州国」]]切手}}) ** Unissued ({{lang-ja|[[:ja:不発行切手|不発行切手]]}}) ** [[Postage stamp booklet|Booklets]] ({{lang-ja|[[:ja:郵便|郵便]][[:ja:切手帳|切手帳]]}}) * Japanese [[Military occupation|Occupation]] Issues (fragments) ({{lang-ja|[[:ja:南方|南方]][[:ja:占領|占領]][[:ja:地域|地域]]切手}} (抜粋)) ** [[Japanese occupation of Burma|Burma]] ({{lang-ja|[[:ja:日本占領時期のビルマ|ビルマ]]}}) ** [[Japanese occupation of the Dutch East Indies|Java]] ({{lang-ja|[[:ja:ジャワ島|ジャワ]]}}) ** Japanese Naval Control Area ({{lang-ja|海軍民政府}}) ** [[Japanese occupation of the Dutch East Indies|Sumatra]] ({{lang-ja|[[:ja:スマトラ島|スマトラ]]}}) ** [[Japanese occupation of Malaya|Malaya]] ({{lang-ja|[[:ja:マラヤ|マラヤ]]}}) ** [[Japanese occupation of the Philippines|Philippine Islands]] ({{lang-ja|[[:ja:日本占領時期のフィリピン|フィリピン]]}}) ** [[Japanese occupation of British Borneo|North Borneo]] ({{lang-ja|[[:ja:英領北ボルネオ|北ボルネオ]]}}) ** [[Japanese occupation of Hong Kong|Hong Kong]] ({{lang-ja|[[:ja:日本占領時期の香港|ホンコン]]}}) ** [Japanese Occupation Issues in [[China]] (fragments)] ({{lang-ja|[[:ja:中国|中国]]占領地域切手}} (抜粋)) *** [[Second Sino-Japanese War|North China]] ({{lang-ja|[[:ja:日中戦争|華北地区]]}}) *** [[Second Sino-Japanese War|Mengkiang]] ({{lang-ja|[[:ja:日中戦争|蒙疆地区]]}}) *** [[Second Sino-Japanese War|Central China]] ({{lang-ja|[[:ja:日中戦争|華中地区]]}})
=== [[Okinawa Prefecture|Okinava]], under [[U.S.]] Administration ({{lang-ja|[[:ja:沖縄切手|沖縄切手]]}}). Till 2014 === * Unissued ({{lang-ja|[[:ja:不発行切手|不発行切手]]}})
=== [[Postal stationery|Postal Stationery]] ({{lang-ja|[[:ja:郵便ステーショナリー|ステーショナリー]]}}). Till 2015 === * [[Postal card|Postal Cards]] ({{lang-ja|〔[[:ja:普通|普通]][[:ja:はがき|はがき]]〕}}) * [[Universal Postal Union|International Mail]] Postal Cards ({{lang-ja|〔[[:ja:万国郵便連合|外信用]][[:ja:はがき|はがき]]〕}}) * Commemorative Postal Cards ({{lang-ja|〔[[:ja:記念|記念]]・[[:ja:特殊|特殊]]はがき〕}}) * New Year's Postal Cards ({{lang-ja|〔[[:ja:お年玉付郵便はがき|年賀はがき]]〕}}) * [[Season]] [[Greeting card|Greeting Postal Cards]] ({{lang-ja|〔[[:ja:季節|季節]]見舞はがき〕}}) * [[The Blue Bird (play)|Blue Bird]] Postal Cards ({{lang-ja|〔[[:ja:青い鳥|青い鳥]]はがき〕}}) * [[Heart (symbol)|Heart]] [[Mail]] ({{lang-ja|〔はあとめーる〕}}) * [[Stamped envelope|Stamped Envelopes]] ({{lang-ja|〔切手つき[[:ja:封筒|封筒]]〕}}) * [[Letter sheet|Letter Sheets]] ({{lang-ja|〔[[:ja:封緘葉書|封緘はがき]]〕}}) * [[Aerogram]]mes ({{lang-ja|〔[[:ja:航空書簡|航空書簡]]〕}}) * Cards for [[Parcel post|Parcel Post]] ({{lang-ja|〔小包はがき〕}}) * [[Wrapper (philately)|Wrappers]] ({{lang-ja|〔[[:ja:小形包装物|郵便帯紙]]〕}}) * For [[Office|Official]] Mail ({{lang-ja|〔事務用はがき〕}}) * [[Weather]] [[Report]]s ({{lang-ja|〔[[:ja:気象|気象]][[:ja:報告|報告]]帯紙〕}}) * For Military Post ({{lang-ja|〔[[:ja:軍事郵便|軍事郵便]]はがき〕}}) * Post Offices Abroad ({{lang-ja|〔在外局発行〕}}) * [[Taiwan]] and [[Korea]] Provisionals ({{lang-ja|〔旧[[:ja:植民地|植民地]]発行〕}})
=== <nowiki>[</nowiki>[[Addendum|Appendix]]<nowiki>]</nowiki> ({{lang-ja|特集}}) (Till 1983?) === * [Some [[Postmark]]s Like “[[Comb]]”] ({{lang-ja|[[:ja:櫛|櫛]][[:ja:型|型]][[:ja:日付印|日付印]]の見わけ方}})

revision.text:
{{Infobox book | name = Seduced by Bacon | title_orig =<!--NA--> | translator =<!--NA--> | image =Seduced by Bacon.jpg | caption = Book cover | author = Joanna Pruess with Bob Lape | illustrator = Liesa Cole | cover_artist = Liesa Cole | country = United States | language = English | series =<!--NA--> | subject = Cook book for bacon | genre =<!--NA--> | publisher = The Lyons Press | pub_date = 1 October 2006 | english_pub_date = | pages = 192 pp | isbn = 1-59228-851-0 | dewey= 641.6/64 22 | congress= TX749.5.P67 P78 2006 | oclc= 61758638 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }}
'''''Seduced by Bacon: Recipes & Lore about America's Favorite Indulgence''''' is a [[cookbook]] about [[bacon]] written by [[Joanna Pruess]] with her husband [[Bob Lape]]. It was first published by [[The Lyons Press]] in 2006 and contains 90 recipes using bacon for breakfast, lunch, and dinner, and even desserts.<ref name="globepequot">{{cite web|url=http://www.globepequot.com/individual_book_page.php?isbn13=9781592288519|title=Seduced by Bacon - publishers page|accessdate=2009-05-13}}</ref>
Pruess is a food writer and consultant to the [[food industry]], and her husband is a [[food critic]] who has written articles for [[Crain Communications Inc.|Crain's business]].
==Description== ''Seduced by Bacon'' contains recipes covering a wide range of bacon-related snacks and meals. It also includes facts, ideas, and instructions for preparing the meat, as well as a brief history of bacon, a discussion of the folklore surrounding the meat, and a glossary of bacon-related items.<ref name="courant">{{cite web|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/courant/access/1170580271.html?dids=1170580271:1170580271&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Nov+30%2C+2006&author=LINDA+GIUCA%3B+Courant+Food+Editor&pub=Hartford+Courant&desc=A+SIZZLING+STORY+OF+SEDUCTION|title=A Sizzling Story of Seduction|last=Giuca|first=Linda|date=2006-11-30|publisher=Hartford Courant|accessdate=2009-05-13}}</ref><ref name="nyt">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/11/22/dining/22book.html?ref=dining|title=Selections Bound to Entice the Cook or the Historian |last=Fabricant|first=Florence|date=2006-11-22|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=2009-05-13}}</ref> The book also provides information on the use of bacon, listing curing techniques, tips on buying and storing bacon and the best ways to cook it.<ref name="nyt"/><ref name="philly" />
''Seduced by Bacon'' includes bacon-related writings from notables such as [[Mark Twain]] and [[Fran Lebowitz]].<ref name="arizona">{{cite news|url=http://www.azstarnet.com/sn/fromcomments_byauthor/161926.php|title=Bring home the bacon — and savor it |last=Sweets|first=Ellen|date=2006-12-27|publisher=Arizona Daily Star|accessdate=2009-05-13}}</ref> It also contains photographs and bacon-related poems: :For us the pig's the means, while bacon is the end :Providing gustatory heights to which we can ascend<ref name="mercury">{{cite news|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/foodheadlines/ci_12036951|title=Piggin' out on bacon at S.F.'s BaconCamp|last=Casey|first=Laura|date=2009-03-31|publisher=San Jose Mercury News|accessdate=2009-05-13}}</ref>
The book claims that 71 percent of bacon is still consumed at breakfast or brunch.<ref name="Delicious">{{cite web | last = Shatzkin | first = Kate | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = A Look at Delicious Ways to Start the Day | work = | publisher = Kitsap Sun | date = 2007-01-10 | url = http://www.kitsapsun.com/news/2007/jan/10/a-look-at-delicious-ways-to-start-the-day/ | doi = | accessdate = 2010-10-15}}</ref> It includes 10 recipes for the early in the day meals and then covers appetizers, sandwiches, entrees and a few desserts, such as a savory bread pudding with Canadian bacon, [[multigrain bread]], feta cheese, tarragon and wild mushrooms "for a sophisticated combination that would be welcome at any meal."<ref name="Delicious"/> In the section on how to cook bacon, Pruess wrote that she prefers to oven-fry large batches in jellyroll pan, in a 400-degree oven for 11 to 16 minutes.<ref name="Delicious"/>
==Reception== First printed on October 1, 2006, ''Seduced by Bacon'' was reprinted 3 times by March 9, 2007.<ref name="nydn">{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/lifestyle/food/2007/02/21/2007-02-21_bring_home_the_bacon_.html|title=Bring Home the Bacon...|date=2007-03-09|last=Wharton|first=Rachel|publisher=NY Daily News|accessdate=2009-05-13}}</ref> It was featured on a Saturday edition of [[CBS]]'s ''[[The Early Show]]'' in a segment called "Chef on a Shoestring", where a three-course meal consisting of recipes from the book was created for four people for $40.<ref name="cbs">{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2006/11/04/earlyshow/saturday/chef/main2153242.shtml|title=Bacon Makes It All Better|date=2006-11-04|publisher=CBS News|accessdate=2009-05-13}}</ref> The menu featured a warm baby spinach salad with oranges, red onion and bacon as a starter; Chinese glazed salmon for the main course and pecan, brown sugar and bacon ice cream for dessert.<ref name="cbs" />
One reviewer described the book as capturing a big food trend: the use of bacon to flavor everything from pasta dishes to sweets.<ref name="philly">{{cite news|url=http://www.philly.com/dailynews/columnists/bernard_fernandez/20070118_inq_food_FD1MORN.html|title=Slow down! Mornings are a time for savoring|last=Shatzkin|first=Kate|date=2007-01-18|publisher=Philadelphia Daily Sun|accessdate=2009-05-13}}</ref> The book has also been mentioned<ref name="buffalo">{{cite news|url=http://www.buffalonews.com/life/taste/article149751.ece|title=Bacon bourbon, bacon scarves, Bacon Camp!|last=Casey|first=Laura|date=2009-04-15|publisher=Contra Costa Times|accessdate=2010-10-15}}</ref> in more recent newspaper stories reporting on bacon's popularity in the United States, a phenomenon sometimes referred to as [[bacon mania]].
==See also== {{Portal|Bacon}} *[[Heather Lauer]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.cbsnews.com/video/watch/?id=2153381n Video of CBS show] {{Bacon}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Seduced By Bacon}} [[Category:2006 books]] [[Category:Cookbooks]] [[Category:Books about bacon]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10ehf1)
revision.text:
{{infobox organization |name = Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation |image = Logo Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation.jpg |size = |formation = 1937 |type = [[Nonprofit organization]] |headquarters = [[New York City|New York, NY]], [[United States]] |leader_title = Director |leader_name = [[Richard Armstrong (museum director)|Richard Armstrong]] | revenue = $89,192,827<ref name="Ratings">{{cite web | url=http://990s.foundationcenter.org/990_pdf_archive/135/135562233/135562233_201512_990.pdf | title=Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation | date= | website=Foundation Center | accessdate=21 November 2017 }}</ref> | revenue_year = 2015 |website = [http://www.guggenheim.org/ www.guggenheim.org] }}
{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2012}} The '''Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation''' is a nonprofit organization founded in 1937 by philanthropist [[Solomon R. Guggenheim]] and his long-time art advisor, artist [[Hilla von Rebay]]. The foundation is a leading institution for the collection, preservation, and research of [[modern art|modern]] and [[contemporary art]] and operates several museums around the world. The first museum established by the foundation was The Museum of Non-Objective Painting, in New York City. This became [[The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum]] in 1952, and the foundation moved the collection into its first permanent museum building, in New York City, in 1959. The foundation next opened the [[Peggy Guggenheim Collection]] in Venice, Italy, in 1980. Its international network of museums expanded in 1997 to include the [[Guggenheim Museum Bilbao]] in [[Bilbao]], Spain, and it expects to open a new museum, [[Guggenheim Abu Dhabi]], in the United Arab Emirates in 2017.
The mission of the foundation is "to promote the understanding and appreciation of art, architecture, and other manifestations of visual culture, primarily of the modern and contemporary periods, and to collect, conserve, and study" modern and contemporary art.<ref>[http://www.guggenheim.org/guggenheim-foundation/mission-statement "Mission Statement"], Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation. Retrieved March 6, 2012</ref> The Foundation seeks, in its constituent museums, to unite distinguished architecture and artworks. The foundation's first permanent museum, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, is housed in a modern spiral building designed by [[Frank Lloyd Wright]], and the Guggenheim Bilbao was designed by [[Frank Gehry]]. Both of these innovative designs received wide press and critical attention. The Peggy Guggenheim Collection is housed in an 18th-century Italian palace, the Palazzo Venier dei Leoni, on the [[Grand Canal (Venice)|Grand Canal]].
The permanent collection of the foundation is based primarily on nine private collections: Solomon R. Guggenheim's collection of [[non-objective art|non-objective]] paintings; Karl Nierendorf's collection of [[German expressionism]] and early [[abstract expressionism]]; [[Katherine S. Dreier]]'s gift of paintings and sculptures; Peggy Guggenheim's collection, concentrating on [[Abstraction (art)|abstraction]] and [[surrealism]]; Justin K. and Hilde Thannhauser's collection of [[impressionist]], [[post-impressionist]], and early modern masterpieces; part of Hilla von Rebay's collection; [[Giuseppe Panza|Giuseppe Panza di Biumo's]] holdings of American [[minimalist art|minimalist]], [[Postminimalism|post-minimalist]], [[Environmental art|environmental]] and [[conceptual art]] of the 1960s and 1970s; a collection of photographs and mixed media from the [[Robert Mapplethorpe]] Foundation; and the Bohen Foundation's collection of film, video, photography and new media.<ref name=cork>[http://www.visual-arts-cork.com/museums/guggenheim-new-york.htm "Guggenheim Museum New York"], ''Encyclopedia of Art'', visual-arts-cork.com. Retrieved April 18, 2012</ref> The foundation's collections have expanded greatly through eight decades and include every major movement of 20th- and 21st-century art. Its directors and curators have attempted to form a single collection that is not encyclopedic, but rather based on their unique visions.<ref>Spector, pp. 6–7</ref> The collection has grown in scope to include new media and performance art, and the foundation has entered into collaborations with YouTube and [[BMW]].
==History==
===Hilla Rebay and early years=== [[Solomon R. Guggenheim]], a member of a wealthy mining family, began collecting works of the [[old masters]] in the 1890s. He retired from his business in 1919 to devote more time to art collecting. In 1926, at age 66, he met artist [[Hilla von Rebay]], who was commissioned by Guggenheim's wife, Irene Rothschild, to paint his portrait.<ref name=artdaily>[http://www.artdaily.com/index.asp?int_sec=11&int_new=31711&int_modo=2 "Exhibition of Works Reflecting the Evolution of the Guggenheim's Collection Opens in Bilbao"], artdaily.org, 2009. Retrieved April 18, 2012</ref> Rebay introduced him to European [[avant-garde]] art, in particular abstract art that she felt had a spiritual and utopian aspect ([[non-objective art]]).<ref name=artdaily/> Guggenheim completely changed his collecting strategy.<ref name=past>[http://pastexhibitions.guggenheim.org/hilla_rebay/biographies_2.html "Biography: Solomon R. Guggenheim"], Art of Tomorrow: Hilla Rebay and Solomon R. Guggenheim, Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation. Retrieved March 8, 2012</ref> In 1930, the two visited [[Wassily Kandinsky]]'s studio in [[Dessau]], Germany, and Guggenheim began to purchase Kandinsky's work. The same year, Guggenheim began to display the collection to the public at his apartment in the [[Plaza Hotel]] in New York City. Guggenheim's purchases continued with the works of [[Rudolf Bauer (artist)|Rudolf Bauer]], [[Fernand Léger]], [[Robert Delaunay]], and great artists who were not of the non-objective school, such as [[Marc Chagall]], [[Jean Metzinger]], [[Albert Gleizes]], [[Pablo Picasso]] and [[László Moholy-Nagy]].<ref name=artdaily/><ref name=past/>
[[File:Paul Klee, 1922, Red Balloon, oil on chalk-primed gauze, mounted on board, 31.7 x 31.1 cm, Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum.jpg|left|thumb|upright|''Red Balloon'' by [[Paul Klee]]]] In 1937, Guggenheim established the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation to foster the appreciation of [[modern art]].<ref name=past/> The foundation's first venue for the display of art was called the "Museum of Non-Objective Painting". It opened in 1939 under the direction of Rebay, its first curator, in a former automobile showroom at East 54th Street in [[midtown Manhattan]].<ref>Vail, pp. 25 and 36</ref> This moved, in 1947, to another rented space at 1071 [[Fifth Avenue]].<ref name=past/> Under Rebay's guidance, Guggenheim sought to include in the collection the most important examples of non-objective art available at the time, such as Kandinsky's ''Composition 8'' (1923), Léger's ''Contrast of Forms'' (1913) and Delaunay's ''Simultaneous Windows'' (2nd Motif, 1st Part)'' (1912).<ref name=Calnek>Calnek, Anthony, et al. ''The Guggenheim Collection'', pp. 39–40, New York: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, 2006</ref>
By the early 1940s, the foundation had accumulated such a large collection of avant-garde paintings that the need for a permanent building to house the art collection had become apparent.<ref name=Winter>Winter, Damon. [http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/organizations/g/guggenheim_solomon_r_museum/index.html "Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum"], ''The New York Times'', October 21, 2009. Retrieved March 7, 2012</ref> In 1943, Guggenheim and Rebay commissioned architect [[Frank Lloyd Wright]] to design the museum building.<ref>Vail, p. 333</ref> Rebay conceived of the space as a "temple of the spirit" that would facilitate a new way of looking at the modern pieces in the collection.<ref>''The Guggenheim: Frank Lloyd Wright and the Making of the Modern Museum'', pp. 217–18, New York: Guggenheim Museum Publications, 2009</ref> In 1948, the collection was greatly expanded through the purchase of art dealer Karl Nierendorf's estate of some 730 objects, notably [[German expressionist]] paintings.<ref name=Calnek/> By that time, the foundation's collection included a broad spectrum of [[expressionist]] and [[surrealist]] works, including paintings by [[Paul Klee]], [[Oskar Kokoschka]] and [[Joan Miró]].<ref name=cork/><ref name=Calnek/> Guggenheim died in 1949, and the museum was renamed the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum]] in 1952. The foundation expanded its display activities with a series of traveling exhibitions.<ref name=Rebaybio>[http://pastexhibitions.guggenheim.org/hilla_rebay/biographies_1.html "Biography: Hilla Rebay"], Art of Tomorrow: Hilla Rebay and Solomon R. Guggenheim, Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation. Retrieved March 8, 2012</ref>
After Guggenheim's death, members of the Guggenheim family who sat on the foundation's board of directors had personal and philosophical differences with Rebay, and in 1952 she resigned as director of the museum.<ref name=Rebaybio/> Nevertheless, she left a portion of her personal collection to the foundation in her will, including works by Kandinsky, Klee, [[Alexander Calder]], Gleizes, [[Piet Mondrian]] and [[Kurt Schwitters]].<ref name=cork/>
===Sweeney and completion of the first building=== [[Image:FrankLloydWright1966USstamp.jpg|thumb|right|1966 U.S. postage stamp honoring Frank Lloyd Wright, showing the Guggenheim in the background]] In 1953, the foundation's collecting boundaries extended even further under its new director, [[James Johnson Sweeney]]. Sweeney rejected Rebay's dismissal of "objective" painting and sculpture, and he soon acquired [[Constantin Brâncuși]]'s ''Adam and Eve'' (1921), followed by works of other modernist sculptors, including [[Jean Arp]], [[Alexander Calder]], [[Alberto Giacometti]] and [[David Smith (sculptor)|David Smith]].<ref name=Calnek/> Sweeney reached beyond the 20th century to acquire [[Paul Cézanne]]'s ''Man with Crossed Arms'' (c. 1899).<ref name=Calnek/> In 1953, the foundation received a gift of 28 important works from the Estate of [[Katherine S. Dreier]], a founder of America's first collection to be called a modern art museum, the [[Société Anonyme]]. Dreier had been a colleague of Rebay's. The works included ''Little French Girl'' (1914–18) by Brâncuși, an untitled still life (1916) by [[Juan Gris]], a bronze sculpture (1919) by [[Alexander Archipenko]] and three collages (1919–21) by German Hanoverian [[Dadaist]] Schwitters. It also included works by Calder, [[Marcel Duchamp]], [[El Lissitzky]] and Mondrian.<ref name=cork/> Among others, Sweeney also acquired the works of [[Alberto Giacometti]], [[David Hayes (sculptor)|David Hayes]], [[Willem de Kooning]] and [[Jackson Pollock]].<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20061001061622/http://www.guggenheim.org/exhibitions/past_exhibitions/global_gugg/global_gugg_bottom_index.html ''The Global Guggenheim''], The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum Publications. Retrieved March 8, 2012</ref> He also established the Guggenheim International Awards in 1956. Sweeney oversaw the last half dozen years of the construction of the museum building, during which time he had an antagonistic relationship with Frank Lloyd Wright, especially regarding the building's lighting issues.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20061001053110/http://www.guggenheim.org/finding_aids/display.php?%2Fsweeney%2F1 "James Johnson Sweeney Administrative papers"], Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum Publications. Retrieved March 8, 2012</ref><ref>Glueck, Grace. "James Johnson Sweeney Dies; Art Critic and Museum Head", ''The New York Times'', April 15, 1986</ref>
The distinctive cylindrical building, wider at the top than the bottom, with a spiral ramp climbing gently from ground level to the skylight at the top, turned out to be Wright's last major work, as the architect died six months before its opening.<ref name=time>[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,892851,00.html "Last Monument"], ''Time'' magazine, November 2, 1959</ref> The building opened in October 1959 to large crowds<ref>Spector, p. 16</ref> and instantly polarized architecture critics,<ref name=time/><ref name=NewsandCourier>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=k4BJAAAAIBAJ&sjid=sQsNAAAAIBAJ&pg=1721,3684938&dq=guggenheim-museum+new+york&hl=en "Controversial Museum Opens in New York"], ''The News and Courier'', October 22, 1959, p. 9-A. Retrieved March 1, 2012</ref> though today it is widely praised.<ref name=USAweekend>[http://www.usaweekend.com/98_issues/981108/981108wright2.html#guggenheim "The Wright Stuff,"]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ''USA Today'' (Weekend). November 6, 1998</ref> Some of the criticism focused on the idea that the building overshadows the artworks displayed inside,<ref name=Winter/> and that it is difficult to properly hang paintings in the shallow, windowless, concave exhibition niches that surround the central spiral. Prior to its opening, twenty-one artists signed a letter protesting the display of their work in such a space.<ref name="time"/> Upon opening, the museum received a largely favorable response from the public, despite the early misgivings: "overall Wright's design was, and still is, admired for being highly personal and inviting".<ref>Wolf, Justin. [http://www.theartstory.org/museum-guggenheim.htm "The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum"], The Art Story Foundation, accessed July 3, 2014</ref>
===Messer and the ramp=== [[File:New York by Piotrus 005.JPG|left|thumb|The Guggenheim's gallery – part of the spiral ramp]] [[Thomas M. Messer]] succeeded Sweeney as director of the museum (but not the foundation) in 1961 and stayed for 27 years, the longest tenure of any of the city's major arts institutions' directors.<ref name=BioInContext>{{Citation |chapter= Thomas M. Messer |title=The Writers Directory |location= Detroit |publisher= [[St. James Press]] |year= 2011 |format=[[Gale (publisher)|Gale Biography In Context Web]] |accessdate=April 11, 2012 }}</ref> When Messer took over, the museum's ability to present art at all was still in doubt due to the challenges presented by continuous spiral ramp gallery that is both tilted and has curved walls.<ref name=Russell1987a>{{Citation |url= https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/05/arts/director-of-guggenheim-retiring-after-27-years.html |accessdate=April 14, 2012 |first= John |last= Russell |title=Director of Guggenheim Retiring After 27 Years |newspaper= [[The New York Times]] |date= November 5, 1987}}</ref> Almost immediately, in 1962, he took a risk putting on a large exhibition that combined the Guggenheim's paintings with sculptures on loan from the [[Hirshhorn Museum]].<ref name=Russell1987a/> Three-dimensional sculpture, in particular, raised "the problem of installing such a show in a museum bearing so close a resemblance to the [[Inferno (Dante)#Overview and vestibule of Hell|circular geography of hell]]", where any vertical object appears tilted in a "drunken lurch" because the slope of the floor and the curvature of the walls could combine to produce vexing optical illusions.<ref name=Canaday1962>{{Citation |title= Museum Director Solves Problem; Guggenheim Official Faces Troubles of Architecture |first= John |last= Canaday |date= August 17, 1962 |newspaper= [[The New York Times]] |pages= 25, 47 }}</ref>
It turned out that the combination could work well in the Guggenheim's space, but, Messer recalled that at the time, "I was scared. I half felt that this would be my last exhibition."<ref name=Russell1987a/> Messer had the foresight to prepare by staging a smaller sculpture exhibition the previous year, in which he discovered how to compensate for the space's weird geometry by constructing special [[plinth]]s at a particular angle, so the pieces were not at a true vertical yet appeared to be so.<ref name=Canaday1962/> In the earlier sculpture show, this trick proved impossible for one piece, an [[Alexander Calder]] [[Mobile (sculpture)|mobile]] whose wire inevitably hung at a true [[Plumb-bob|plumb]] vertical, "suggesting hallucination" in the disorienting context of the tilted floor.<ref name=Canaday1962/>
The next year, Messer acquired a private collection from art dealer Justin K. Thannhauser for the foundation's permanent collection.<ref>Decker, Andrew. [http://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/interviews/oral-history-interview-thomas-m-messer-11803 "Oral History Interview with Thomas M. Messer, 1994 Oct.-1995 Jan."], ''Archives of American Art'', January 25, 1995. Retrieved March 13, 2012</ref> These 73 works include [[Impressionist]], [[Post-Impressionist]] and French modern masterpieces, including important works by [[Paul Gauguin]], [[Édouard Manet]], [[Camille Pissarro]], [[Vincent van Gogh]] and 32 works by [[Pablo Picasso]].<ref name=cork/><ref>[http://research.frick.org/directoryweb/browserecord.php?-action=browse&-recid=7357 "Thannhauser, Justin K.:] [[The Frick Collection]]", ''Archives Directory for the History of Collecting in America''. Retrieved March 13, 2012</ref>
===Global expansion=== {{main|Peggy Guggenheim Collection|Guggenheim Museum Bilbao|Deutsche Guggenheim}} [[File:Peggy guggenheim museum.JPG|thumb|left|The [[Peggy Guggenheim Collection]], in Venice]] [[Peggy Guggenheim]], Solomon's niece, collected and displayed art beginning in 1938.<ref name="Biography of Peggy Guggenheim">{{Citation |url= http://www.guggenheim-venice.it/inglese/museum/peggy.html |title= Peggy Guggenheim |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20130315192409/http://guggenheim-venice.it/inglese/museum/peggy.html |archivedate=March 15, 2013 |publisher= [[Peggy Guggenheim Collection]] |accessdate= June 25, 2010 }}</ref> At Messer's urging, she donated her art collection and home in Venice, the ''Palazzo Venier dei Leoni'', to the foundation in 1976.<ref>Vail, Karole. ''Peggy Guggenheim: A Celebration'', p. 77, Guggenheim Museum Publications: New York, 1998</ref> After her death in 1979, the collection of more than 300 works was re-opened to the public as the [[Peggy Guggenheim Collection]] in 1980 by the foundation, which was then under the direction of Peter Lawson-Johnston.<ref>Tacou-Rumney, p. 171</ref><ref name=Priceless>Walsh, John. [https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/features/the-priceless-peggy-guggenheim-1806124.html "The priceless Peggy Guggenheim"], ''The Independent'', October 21, 2009. Retrieved March 12, 2012</ref> It includes early 20th century works of prominent American modernists and Italian [[futurism (art)|futurist]]s. Pieces in the collection embrace [[Cubism]], [[Surrealism]] and [[Abstract expressionism]]. Some of the notable artists are Picasso, [[Salvador Dalí|Dalí]], [[René Magritte|Magritte]], [[Constantin Brâncuși|Brâncuși]] (including a sculpture from the ''[[Bird in Space]]'' series), eleven works by Pollock, [[Georges Braque|Braque]], [[Marcel Duchamp|Duchamp]], [[Fernand Léger|Léger]], [[Gino Severini|Severini]], [[Picabia]], [[Giorgio de Chirico|de Chirico]], [[Piet Mondrian|Mondrian]], Kandinsky, Miró, [[Alberto Giacometti|Giacometti]], Klee, [[Arshile Gorky|Gorky]], Calder, [[Max Ernst]] and Peggy Guggenheim's daughter, [[Pegeen Vail Guggenheim]].<ref name=cork/><ref name="Biography of Peggy Guggenheim"/>
Since 1985, the United States has selected the foundation to operate the U.S. Pavilion of the [[Venice Biennale]], an exhibition held every other summer. In 1986, the foundation purchased the Palladian-style pavilion, built in 1930.<ref name=Priceless/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guggenheim-venice.it/inglese/pavilion/index.php |title=US Pavilion |work=Peggy Guggenheim Collection |publisher=The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation |accessdate=October 22, 2011}}</ref>
[[Thomas Krens]], director of the foundation from 1988 to 2008, led a rapid expansion of the foundation's collections.<ref>Carol Vogel. [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/28/arts/design/28muse.html?_r=1 "Guggenheim’s Provocative Director Steps Down"], ''The New York Times'', February 28, 2008. Retrieved March 8, 2012</ref> In 1991, he broadened the foundation's holdings by acquiring the Panza Collection. Assembled by [[Giuseppe Panza|Count Giuseppe di Biumo]] and his wife, Giovanna, the Panza Collection includes examples of [[Minimalist art|Minimalist]] sculptures by [[Carl Andre]], [[Dan Flavin]] and [[Donald Judd]], and Minimalist paintings by [[Robert Mangold]], [[Brice Marden]] and [[Robert Ryman]], as well as an array of [[Post-minimalism|Post-Minimal]], [[Conceptual art|Conceptual]], and perceptual art by [[Robert Morris (artist)|Robert Morris]], [[Richard Serra]], [[James Turrell]], [[Lawrence Weiner]] and others, notably American examples of the 1960s and 1970s.<ref name=cork/><ref name=Glueck>Glueck, Grace. [https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/05/arts/guggenheim-may-sell-artworks-to-pay-for-a-major-new-collection.html?pagewanted=all "Guggenheim May Sell Artworks to Pay for a Major New Collection"], ''The New York Times'', March 5, 1990, accessed March 13, 2012</ref> In 1992, the [[Robert Mapplethorpe]] Foundation gifted 200 of his best photographs to the foundation. The works spanned his entire output, from his early collages, [[Polaroid camera|Polaroids]], portraits of celebrities, self-portraits, male and female nudes, flowers and statues. It also featured mixed-media constructions and included his well-known 1998 ''Self-Portrait''. The acquisition initiated the foundation's photography exhibition program.<ref name=cork/>
Also in 1992, the New York museum building's exhibition and other space was expanded by the addition of an adjoining rectangular tower, taller than the original spiral, and a renovation of the original building.<ref name=GSwebsite>[http://www.gwathmey-siegel.com Overview of firm's history, projects, etc.] Gwathmey Siegel website</ref> The same year, the foundation opened a small [[Guggenheim Museum SoHo]] in the [[SoHo]] neighborhood of downtown Manhattan. This space was kept after the main museum was re-opened, but it closed in 2002 due to an economic downturn.{{Citation needed|date=March 2012}} To finance these moves, controversially, the foundation sold works by Kandinsky, Chagall and [[Amedeo Modigliani|Modigliani]] to raise $47 million, drawing considerable criticism for trading masters for "trendy" latecomers. In ''The New York Times'', critic [[Michael Kimmelman]] wrote that the sales "stretched the accepted rules of [[Deaccessioning#Deaccessioning|deaccessioning]] further than many American institutions have been willing to do."<ref name=Kimmelman1998>{{Citation |last= Kimmelman |first= Michael |title = Art View; The High Cost of Selling Art |date= April 1, 1990 |newspaper= [[New York Times]] |url= https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/01/arts/art-view-the-high-cost-of-selling-art.html |accessdate=April 9, 2012 }}</ref> Krens defended the action as consistent with the museum's principles, including expanding its international collection and building its "postwar collection to the strength of our pre-war holdings"<ref name=Glueck/> and pointed out that such sales are a regular practice by museums.<ref name=Kimmelman1998/>
[[File:Guggenheim-bilbao-jan05.jpg|thumb|300px|The [[Guggenheim Museum Bilbao]], along the [[Nervión|Nervión River]] in downtown [[Bilbao]]]] One of Krens's most significant initiatives was to expand the foundation's international presence.<ref>Russell, James S. [https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=a3nVuX5IVJCE "Guggenheim’s Krens Eyes Hudson Yards Museum, Seeks New Bilbaos"], Bloomberg, March 11, 2008. Retrieved March 13, 2012</ref> The [[Guggenheim Museum Bilbao]] opened in 1997. Designed by [[Frank Gehry]], the titanium, glass and limestone Guggenheim Bilbao is a centerpiece of the revitalization of the [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basque]] city of [[Bilbao]], Spain.<ref name=praise>{{cite news|title=Bilbao's Cinderella Story| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/08/08/travel/bilbao-s-cinderella-story.html?scp=10&sq=guggenheim%20museum%20bilbao&st=cse| author=Warren Hodge| date=August 8, 1999|work=The New York Times| accessdate=October 21, 2011}}</ref> The building was greeted with glowing praise from architecture critics.<ref>Stoller, p. 3</ref> The Basque government funded the construction, while the Foundation purchased the artworks and manages the facility.<ref name=praise/> The museum's permanent collection includes works by modern and contemporary Basque and Spanish artists like [[Eduardo Chillida]], [[Juan Munoz]] and [[Antonio Saura]], as well as works from the foundation, and it has organized various exhibitions curated by the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York.<ref>Stoller, pp. 3–4</ref>
Also in 1997, the foundation opened a small gallery in the [[Unter den Linden]] area of Berlin, Germany, as the [[Deutsche Guggenheim]], in cooperation with the Deutsche Bank.<ref name=Winter/> The Deutsche Guggenheim had four exhibitions each year, complemented by educational programming, and it annually commissioned one, or occasionally two, new artworks or series by contemporary artists, which were then displayed at the museum in a special exhibition.<ref>[http://www.berlin.de/orte/museum/deutsche-guggenheim-berlin/index.en.php?lang=en "Deutsche Guggenheim Berlin"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121105111223/http://www.berlin.de/orte/museum/deutsche-guggenheim-berlin/index.en.php?lang=en |date=November 5, 2012 }}, Guggenheim Foundation. Retrieved March 13, 2012</ref> After 14 years of operation, Deutsche Guggenheim closed at the end of 2012.<ref>Vogel, Carol. [http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/02/06/guggenheim-to-close-berlin-outpost/ "Guggenheim to Close Berlin Outpost"], ''The New York Times'', February 6, 2012. Retrieved March 13, 2012</ref>
===Later activities=== Under Krens, the foundation mounted some of its most popular exhibitions: "Africa: The Art of a Continent" in 1996; "China: 5,000 Years" in 1998, "Brazil: Body & Soul" in 2001; and "The Aztec Empire" in 2004.<ref>Carol Vogel (April 27, 2005) [https://www.nytimes.com/2005/04/27/arts/design/27kren.html?pagewanted=2&ref=thomaskrens "A Museum Visionary Envisions More"], ''The New York Times''. Retrieved February 2, 2011</ref> It has shown unusual exhibitions on occasion, for example [[commercial art]] installations of [[Giorgio Armani]] suits and motorcycles. ''[[The New Criterion]]'''s [[Hilton Kramer]] condemned both ''[[The Art of the Motorcycle]]''<ref>{{Citation |last=Plagens |first=Peter |date=September 7, 1998|title=Rumble on the Ramps.('The Art of the Motorcycle,' Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, New York, New York) |periodical=Newsweek |volume=132 |issue=10 |page=80 }}</ref> and the retrospective of the work of fashion designer Armani.<ref name=Kramer>{{Citation |last=Kramer |first=Hilton |date=December 11, 2000 |title=Gehry's New Guggenheim Is Kitschy Theme Park |periodical=The New York Observer |location=New York, NY |url=http://www.observer.com/node/43748 }}</ref> Others disagreed.<ref name=Sudjic/> A 2009 retrospective of Frank Lloyd Wright at the original building in New York showcased the architect on the 50th anniversary of the opening of the building and was the museum's most popular exhibit since it began keeping such attendance records in 1992.<ref name=Winter/>
[[File:Guggenheim Las Vegas 02.jpg|thumb|left|upright|''[[The Art of the Motorcycle]]'' exhibition in Las Vegas]] In 2001, the foundation opened two new museums in Las Vegas, [[Guggenheim Las Vegas]] and [[Guggenheim Hermitage Museum]], both designed by architect [[Rem Koolhaas]]. The museums showcased highlights of the collections, respectively, of the foundation and the [[Hermitage Museum]] in [[Saint Petersburg]], Russia.<ref name=Peterson1>Peterson, Kristen. [http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2008/apr/10/vegas-say-goodbye-guggenheim/ "Vegas, Say Goodbye to Guggenheim"], ''Las Vegas Sun'', April 10, 2008. Retrieved March 14, 2012</ref><ref>Tinturier, Sandrine. [http://www.palacity.com/ultimate/guggenheim-las-vegas.php "Guggenheim Museum in Las Vegas"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714183524/http://www.palacity.com/ultimate/guggenheim-las-vegas.php |date=July 14, 2014 }}, Palacity.com, 2002, accessed July 3, 2014</ref> The first and larger of the two hosted one exhibition: "The Art of the Motorcycle", before closing in 2003.<ref name=Bohlen2002>{{Citation |last=Bohlen |first=Celestine |date=December 24, 2002 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|title=Retrenching Guggenheim Closes Hall In Las Vegas |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/12/24/arts/retrenching-guggenheim-closes-hall-in-las-vegas.html |accessdate=October 21, 2011}}</ref> The latter, held ten exhibitions of masterworks by leading artists from the last six centuries, including [[Jan van Eyck|Van Eyck]], [[Titian]], [[Diego Velázquez|Velázquez]], [[Vincent van Gogh|Van Gogh]], [[Pablo Picasso|Picasso]], [[Jackson Pollock|Pollock]] and [[Roy Lichtenstein|Lichtenstein]]. The Guggenheim Hermitage Museum closed in 2008.<ref name=Peterson1/>
In 2001 the foundation also established the Sackler Center for Arts Education on the campus of the original New York building.<ref name=Sackler>[http://www.guggenheim.org/new-york/education/sackler-center "Sackler Center for Arts Education"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140209061825/http://www.guggenheim.org/new-york/education/sackler-center |date=February 9, 2014 }}, The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation. Retrieved March 21, 2012</ref> The same year, the foundation received a gift of the large collection of the Bohen Foundation, which, for two decades, commissioned new works of art with an emphasis on film, video, photography and new media. Artists included in the collection are [[Pierre Huyghe]], [[Sophie Calle]] and [[Jac Leirner]].<ref name=artdaily/> The foundation planned for a large Guggenheim museum on the waterfront in lower [[Manhattan]], and it engaged Frank Gehry as the architect. His essentially complete designs for the building were showcased in 2001 at the Fifth Avenue museum,<ref>[http://www.arcspace.com/gehry_new/index.html?main=/gehry_new/gug_ny/gug_ny.html "Guggenheim Museum New York"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131106023237/http://www.arcspace.com/gehry_new/index.html?main=%2Fgehry_new%2Fgug_ny%2Fgug_ny.html |date=November 6, 2013 }}, An Arce Space Catalogue. Retrieved March 14, 2012</ref> but these plans were disrupted by the economic downturn of the early 2000s and the [[September 11, 2001 attacks]], which prompted reconsideration of any plans in lower Manhattan.<ref>Lieberman, Paul. [http://articles.latimes.com/2000/nov/29/entertainment/ca-58498 "New York Mayor Backs Waterfront Guggenheim"], ''Los Angeles Times'', November 29, 2000. Retrieved March 14, 2012</ref> Other projects in [[Rio de Janeiro]], [[Vilnius]], [[Salzburg]],<ref>Fowler, Brenda. [https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/13/arts/salzburg-guggenheim-offshoot-exists-in-hopes-and-blueprints.html "Salzburg Guggenheim Offshoot Exists in Hopes and Blueprints"], ''The New York Times'', August 13, 1990, accessed July 3, 2014</ref> [[Guadalajara]]<ref>Kaufman, Jason Edward. [http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Why-the-Guggenheim-wont-open-a-branch-in-Guadalajara-/8576 "Why the Guggenheim won’t open a branch in Guadalajara"], ''The Art Newspaper'', Museums, Issue 192, June 1, 2008; {{cite news |title=Cancela proyecto la fundación Solomon R. Guggenheim en Guadalajara |url=http://www.informador.com.mx/cultura/2009/149027/6/cancela-proyecto-la-fundacion-solomon-r-guggenheim-en-guadalajara.htm |newspaper=El Informador |location=Guadalajara, Mexico |date=26 October 2009 |accessdate= |trans-title=Solomon R. Guggenheim foundation cancels project}}</ref> and [[Taichung]] were also considered but not completed.
On January 19, 2005, the philanthropist [[Peter Lewis (businessman)|Peter B. Lewis]] resigned from his position as chairman of the foundation, expressing his opposition to Krens' plans for further global expansion of the Guggenheim museums. Lewis had been the largest donor in the history of the Guggenheim.<ref name="Lewis">Vogel, Carol. [https://www.nytimes.com/2005/01/20/arts/design/20museum.html?ref=peterblewis "Guggenheim Loses Top Donor in Rift on Spending and Vision"], January 20, 2005, ''The New York Times'', accessed December 6, 2012</ref> Tensions continued, however, and on February 27, 2008, Krens resigned from his position in the foundation. He has remained, however, as an advisor for international affairs.<ref name="krens">{{cite news| title= Provocative Guggenheim director resigns| url= https://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/28/arts/28iht-gugg.1.10523443.html?scp=1&sq=guggenheim%20peter%20lewis%20resign&st=cse| date=February 28, 2008| author=Carol Lewis|work=The New York Times| accessdate=October 21, 2011}}</ref> Over his two decades at the head of the foundation, Krens was criticized not only for the deaccessioning of older works of the museum<ref name=Kimmelman1998/> but for both his businesslike style and perceived populism and commercialization.<ref name=Sudjic>{{Citation |last=Sudjic |first=Deyan |date=January 23, 2005 |title=Is this the end of the Guggenheim dream? |periodical=The Observer |location=London, UK |publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited |url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2005/jan/23/art.museums}}</ref><ref>{{Citation |last=Gibson |first=Eric |date=November 27, 1998 |title=For Museums, Bigger Is Better |periodical=The Wall Street Journal |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB911879208127582000 }}</ref> One writer commented, "Krens has been both praised and vilified for turning what was once a small New York institution into a worldwide brand, creating the first truly multinational arts institution. ... Krens transformed the Guggenheim into one of the best-known brand name in the arts."<ref>{{Citation |last=Mahoney |first=Sarah |date=October 2, 2006 |title=Thomas Krens |periodical=Advertising Age |volume=77 |issue=40 |page= I-8 }}</ref>
[[File:Richard Armstrong 2012.png|right|thumb|upright|Richard Armstrong, 2012]] [[Richard Armstrong (museum director)|Richard Armstrong]] became the fifth director of the foundation on November 4, 2008. He had been director of the [[Carnegie Museum of Art]] in [[Pittsburgh]], Pennsylvania for 12 years, where he had also served as chief curator and curator of contemporary art.<ref>Vogel, Carol. [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/24/arts/design/24muse.html?_r=1&ref=richardarmstrong "Guggenheim Chooses a Curator, Not a Showman"], ''The New York Times'', September 23, 2008. Retrieved March 14, 2012</ref> In addition to its permanent collections, which continue to grow,<ref name=artdaily/> the foundation administers loan exhibitions and co-organizes exhibitions with other museums to foster public outreach.<ref name=websiteCollab>[http://www.guggenheim.org/guggenheim-foundation/collaborations Foundation website's collaborations page] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140405012929/http://www.guggenheim.org/guggenheim-foundation/collaborations |date=April 5, 2014 }}</ref>
In 2006, [[Abu Dhabi]], the capital of the United Arab Emirates, announced an agreement with the Guggenheim Foundation to build a new museum, "[[Guggenheim Abu Dhabi]]". Gehry designed the structure,<ref name="abu dhabi">{{cite news| url= https://www.nytimes.com/2006/07/09/world/middleeast/09gugg.html?scp=2&sq=guggenheim%20museum%20abu%20dhabi&st=cse| author=Carol Vogel| title=Guggenheim Foundation and Abu Dhabi Plan Museum There| work=The New York Times| date=July 9, 2006| accessdate=October 21, 2011}}</ref> which will, if completed, be the foundation's largest by far.<ref name=helsinki/> It has begun construction on the northwest tip of [[Saadiyat Island]],<ref name=Priceless/> along with a performing arts center, the [[Zayed National Museum]] and a branch of the [[Musée du Louvre|Louvre]].<ref name="saadiyat">{{cite web| title=Saadiyat Cultural District| url=http://www.guggenheim.org/abu-dhabi/about/cultural-district| publisher=Guggenheim Foundation| accessdate=October 21, 2011| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111118105118/http://www.guggenheim.org/abu-dhabi/about/cultural-district| archivedate=November 18, 2011| df=mdy-all}}</ref> The museum is expected to "create an exhibition space intended to turn this once-sleepy desert city along the Persian Gulf into an international arts capital and tourist destination."<ref>Fatah, Hassan. [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/01/arts/design/01isla.html?scp=83&sq=&st=nyt "Celebrity Architects Reveal a Daring Cultural Xanadu for the Arab World"], ''The New York Times'', February 1, 2007. Retrieved April 2, 2012</ref> The completion date has been pushed back repeatedly, and the museum is now expected to open in 2017 at the earliest.<ref name=Adam2011>Adam, Georgina. [http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Guggenheim+Abu+Dhabi+on+hold/24880 "Guggenheim Abu Dhabi on Hold"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111231025217/http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Guggenheim+Abu+Dhabi+on+hold/24880 |date=December 31, 2011 }}, ''The Art Newspaper'', October 24, 2011.
