revision.text:
{{About|a media term|other uses of the acronym 'WAG'|Wag (disambiguation)}} {{Multiple issues| {{Lead too short|date=July 2009}} {{Original research|date=November 2008}} {{Criticism section|date=October 2009}} }} {{Use British English|date=January 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} '''WAGs''' (or '''Wags''') is an [[acronym]] used to refer to '''wives and girlfriends''' of high-profile [[sportspersons]]. The term may also be used in the singular form, '''WAG''', to refer to a specific female partner or life partner who is in a relationships with an athlete.
The term was first used by the British [[tabloid (newspaper format)|tabloid]] press to refer to the wives and girlfriends of high-profile [[association football|footballers]], originally the [[England national football team]]. It came into common use during the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]], although the term had been used occasionally before that. The acronym has since been used by the media in other countries to describe the female partners of [[sportsperson|sportspeople]] in general.
== Lexicography ==
It is popular belief that the first recorded use of the term WAG was in 2002: "It was never guaranteed that the wives and girlfriends (or "the Wags", as staff at the Jumeirah Beach Club call them for short) would get along. Mrs Beckham's tongue, for one thing, has previously run away with itself."<ref name="Sunday Telegraph, 19 May 2002">''Sunday Telegraph'', 19 May 2002</ref>
In 2006 it was generally printed as "WAGs", but a singular, "Wag" or "WAG", quickly came into vogue for example: "any additional pounds she gained during Wag drinking sessions";<ref>''Metro'', 4 July 2006</ref> "a property heiress, model and actress, appears a likely sports WAG".<ref name="Times, 3 July 2006">''Times'', 3 July 2006</ref> [[Susie Dent]]'s annual ''[[Language Report]]'' for the Oxford University Press (2006) capitalised the entire acronym as "WAG" ("'''w'''ife '''a'''nd/or '''g'''irlfriend") .<ref>Susie Dent (2006) ''The like, Language Report for real''</ref>
"WAG"/"wag" came also to be used somewhat [[RAS syndrome|redundantly]] ("deluxe-edition Wag girlfriend"<ref>Rod Liddle, ''Sunday Times'', 13 August 2006</ref>), although in such usage "girlfriend" (or "wife") could be interpreted as further denotative specification within the set of people fitting both the denotation and the connotation of "WAG", and increasingly in non-footballing contexts: for example, the first wife of comedian [[Peter Cook]] (1937–95) was described as a "Sixties Wag"<ref>''Sunday Times News Review'', 24 September 2006</ref> and actress [[Jennifer Ellison]], because of her former choice of clothes, "once ... the epitome of a Wag".<ref>Reference was made to Ellison's erstwhile "short skirt, high heels, long talons and hair extensions" and the tenuous fact that she had once stepped out briefly with Liverpool and England player Steven Gerrard: ''London Lite'', 5 October 2006.</ref> Fashion writer Shane Watson coined a [[collective noun]], "waggery".<ref>''Sunday Times Style'', 17 September 2006</ref> One can also be "Wagged"
This type of acronym is of long standing in British English. For example, during the Second World War, a series of [[County War Agricultural Executive Committees]] or CWAECs was known widely as "War Ags".<ref>Daniel Smith (2011) ''The Spade as Mighty as the Sword''</ref>
== 2006 World Cup == During the [[2006 FIFA World Cup|2006 World Cup]] the press gave increasing coverage to the socialising and shopping activities of the English WAGs, who were based in the German town of [[Baden-Baden]]. It was frequently suggested that England's exit from the tournament in the quarterfinals was a result of such distractions.
Prominent WAGs of that year included [[Victoria Beckham]], wife of then England captain [[David Beckham]], whom the ''New Yorker'' described as "Queen of the Wags"<ref>''New Yorker'', 3 July 2006</ref> and the ''Sunday Times'' as "the original Wag";<ref>''Sunday Times'', 20 August 2006</ref> [[Cheryl (singer)|Cheryl]], ''née'' Tweedy, of the group [[Girls Aloud]], who shortly afterwards married [[Ashley Cole]] ("Wag weds"<ref>Mirror'', 16 July 2006</ref>), from whom she was divorced in 2010; [[Coleen Rooney]], ''née'' Mcloughlin, who married [[Wayne Rooney]] in June 2008 and who was variously described as a "[[chav]]ette", by ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' a "super WAG"<ref>''The Sun'', 6 July 2006</ref> and, by the end of the year, listed by the ''Times'' as a "[[national treasure]]";<ref>''Times Magazine'', 23 December 2006</ref> and fitness instructor [[Carly Cole]] née Zucker, wife of [[Joe Cole]], described by Susie Whally in the ''Sunday Times'' as a "new WAG on the block [who] has set the tone for the season's most wanted muscles".<ref>''Style'', 9 July 2006</ref> Other WAGs that aroused considerable interest included [[Melanie Slade]], due to her relative youth – she was an [[Advanced Level (UK)|A-level]] student at the time – girlfriend of [[Theo Walcott]], who, at seventeen, was himself the youngest member of the England squad; [[Abbey Clancy]], girlfriend of [[Peter Crouch]]; [[Steven Gerrard]]'s fiancé [[Alex Curran]], a model frequently featured in tabloids and fashion magazines; and former Spanish waitress [[Elen Rives]], the then fiancée of [[Frank Lampard]].
[[Nancy Dell'Olio]], an Italian property lawyer who was the girlfriend of the then England coach [[Sven-Göran Eriksson]], enjoyed quite a high public profile of her own, partly as a result of long-running press interest in aspects of Eriksson's private life.
== Notable == There are many celebrities who are also considered WAGs, by either marrying or dating a notable athlete. Some famous WAGs include [[La La Anthony]], [[Victoria Beckham]], [[Gisele Bündchen]], [[Cheryl (singer)|Cheryl]], [[Ciara]], [[Ayesha Curry]], [[Hilary Duff]], [[Savannah James]], [[Khloe Kardashian]], [[Carrie Underwood]] and [[Gabrielle Union]].
=== Political comparisons === The WAGs' activities did however provide a "benchmark" of sorts. A [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] member of the UK Parliament, [[Denis MacShane]], described the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party's]] summer [[ball (dance)|ball]] of 2006 (for which tickets cost £400) as "mak[ing] the WAGs of Baden Baden look like the [[Bloomsbury set]]",<ref>''Times'', 8 July 2006</ref> a comparison with the [[Bohemian style|"Bohemian"]] artistic group of the early 20th century that grew up initially around sisters [[Vanessa Bell]] and [[Virginia Woolf]].
Leo Beckett, husband of British Foreign Secretary [[Margaret Beckett]] was described as the "political equivalent of a WAG" because of the extent to which he accompanied his wife on official business.<ref>Roland White, ''Sunday Times'', 23 July 2006</ref>
=== Implications for fashion === <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Coleen McLoughlin - Times Magazine.JPG|thumb|[[Coleen Rooney]] (''née'' Mcloughlin) modelling for [[Asda|George at Asda]]: ''Times Magazine'', 9 September 2006]] -->
Fashion writers of 2006 identified certain consequences of what [[Lisa Armstrong]] described as "WAG fall-out"<ref name="Times Magazine, 15 July 2006">''Times Magazine'', 15 July 2006</ref> and Tina Gaudoin as "Waglash".<ref>''Times Magazine'', 5 August 2006</ref> These were mostly the implications of "over-exposure" of certain styles: for example, that the [[Hermès]] "[[Birkin Bag|Birkin]]" bag had become less desirable as a result of being ''de rigueur'' among WAGs in Baden-Baden<ref>''Style'', 25 June 2006</ref> (a development dubbed by Shane Watson as "baglash"<ref>''Style'', 6 August 2006</ref>); or that reaction to WAGs’ excessively coiffed hair and "vacant perfection" had perhaps been the "tipping point" for a revival of fashions of the 1980s, commended by Armstrong as "the last era of anti-slick".<ref name="Times Magazine, 15 July 2006"/>
Armstrong also assured readers who wished to perfect the elements of "[[Chic: A-L#Beach chic|beach chic]]" that the use of denture cleaner to whiten the tips of nails would not make them "look like a WAG",<ref name="Times Magazine, 22 July 2006">''Times Magazine'', 22 July 2006</ref> while her colleague Sarah Vine offered advice on "buying some nice perfume that won't make you smell like a WAG on heat".<ref name="Times Magazine, 22 July 2006"/> When it was reported, in 2007, that [[Coleen Rooney]] would be launching a range of beauty products, ''London Lite'' coined the term, ''"eau de wag"'' and asked, "who, tell us, who really wants to smell like Coleen McLoughlin?"<ref>Clare Coleman, ''London Lite'', 14 May 2007</ref>
====Wannabes==== However, some women did aspire to the "WAG" look. Mrs Rooney noted that "apparently more and more women are getting into debt because they try to shop and party like a footballer's wife. If I heard of anyone doing that, I'd tell them to get a grip".<ref>''Closer'', quoted in ''Sunday Times'', 3 September 2006</ref> ''Sunday Times'' columnist [[India Knight]] observed, while waiting in an airport queue, that "it's as if a low-level wannabe footballer's wife vibe that is neither aesthetically pleasing nor edifying has become the norm ... I saw this phenomenon ''en masse''".<ref name="Sunday Times, 3 September 2006">''Sunday Times'', 3 September 2006</ref> Among other features, Knight identified "enough pink glitter to satisfy the [[girly girl|girliest]] of five-year-olds", massive handbags and huge designer sunglasses.
Reflecting on sunglasses as an accessory, ''Sunday Times Style'''s senior fashion writer Colin McDowell suggested that, whereas women had been sure that the poise of [[Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis|Jacqueline Kennedy]] (1929–94) and [[Audrey Hepburn]] (1929–93), style icons of the mid-20th century, had been due to their shading their eyes, "Wags ... far from using dark glasses to encourage others to leave them alone, treat them as a weapon to attract and excite the [[paparazzi]]".<ref>''Style'', 30 July 2006</ref>
== Antecedents == Interest in the partners of footballers dates back at least to the late 1950s when the long-serving England captain [[Billy Wright (footballer born 1924)|Billy Wright]] married the singer [[The Beverley Sisters|Joy Beverley]]. By the late 1960s, then-captain [[Bobby Moore]] (1941–93) and his first wife Tina had become regarded as a stylish and "golden" couple. During the [[1970 FIFA World Cup|1970 World Cup]] in Mexico the England manager [[Sir Alf Ramsey]] (1920–99) expressed concern at the effects on the team's cohesion of the presence of the wives of four players,<ref>Tina Moore, Frances Bonetti (wife of Peter Bonetti), Judith, later Lady Hurst ([[Geoff Hurst]]) and Kathy Peters ([[Martin Peters]]).</ref> a view that seems to have been shared by some other members of the squad.<ref name="Leo McKinstry 2006 Sir Alf">Leo McKinstry (2006) ''Sir Alf''</ref> England's quarter-final defeat by [[West Germany]] in that competition has been widely attributed to [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeping]] lapses by [[Peter Bonetti]], whose pre-match nerves were thought by many, including Ramsey himself, to have been accentuated by rumours circulating about the alleged behaviour of his wife Frances.<ref name="Leo McKinstry 2006 Sir Alf"/> By contrast, during the 1966 World Cup, their wives drove themselves to Wembley and the FA booked them a single function room in the Royal Garden Hotel at Kensington.
Interest in such partnerships scaled new heights in the late 1990s and early 21st century with the marriage (in 1999) of [[David Beckham]] to singer [[Victoria Beckham|Victoria Adams]] ("Posh Spice") of the [[Spice Girls]]. The couple were widely known as "Posh and Becks" and every aspect of their relationship and nuance of dress were subjected to scrutiny in the press and other media. Victoria Beckham was quoted as saying that she and her husband had "so many wider interests ... fashion, make-up. I mean you think, yeah, football's great, and singing's great. But you've got to look at the bigger picture".<ref>[[Susie Dent]] (2003) ''The Language Report''</ref>
Former Manchester United captain [[Roy Keane]] had lashed out at footballers' wives and girlfriends, as well as their lavish lifestyle, during their trophyless season in 2001–2002. Keane blamed United's loss of form on some of his teammates' fixation with wealth, claiming that they had "forgot about the game, lost the hunger that got you the Rolex, the cars, the mansion." Earlier in the season, Keane had publicly advocated the break-up of the Treble-winning team<ref name="vieira">{{Cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/article511049.ece |title=The top 10 Roy Keane battles |work=The Times |location=London |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070309065831/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/article511049.ece |archivedate=9 March 2007 }}</ref> as he believed the teammates who had played in United's victorious 1999 Champions League final no longer had the motivation to work as hard.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/main.jhtml?xml=/sport/2005/11/19/sfnroy19.xml |title=Keane exits still raging at the dying of the light |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London | first=Tim | last=Rich | date=19 November 2005 | accessdate=27 May 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/08/15/sports/EU-SPT-SOC-Keane-WAGS.php |title=Search – Global Edition – The New York Times |work=International Herald Tribune |date=29 March 2009 |accessdate=7 July 2009}}</ref> When Keane became manager of [[Sunderland A.F.C]], he complained about the difficulty signing players to the city in northeast England, as their wives or girlfriends insisted they only move to teams based in London. He remarked "If someone doesn't want to come to Sunderland then all well and good," Keane said. "But if they don't want to come to Sunderland because their wife wants to go shopping in London, then it is a sad state of affairs. Unfortunately that is what is influencing a lot of footballers' decisions. Priorities have changed for footballers and they are being dictated to by their wives and girlfriends."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2007/aug/15/football.britishidentity |title=Roy Keane sees red again with outburst about Wags and their shopping jaunts | UK news |work=The Guardian |location=London |date= 15 August 2007|accessdate=7 July 2009 | first=Louise | last=Taylor}}</ref>
=== ''Footballers' Wives'' === [[File:Fw1DVD.jpg|thumb|''Footballers' Wives'', 2002 (DVD of ITV drama series)]]
It was widely assumed that perceptions of the lifestyle of [[Victoria Beckham]] influenced the ITV drama series ''[[Footballers' Wives]]'' (2002) and in particular the character of Chardonnay Lane-Pascoe (played by [[Susie Amy]]). The term "footballer's wife" came to be associated with a spouse leading a "high" life of socialising and shopping. Alf Ramsey, who thought the role of a footballer's wife essentially that of a housewife,<ref>"A footballer's wife needs to run the home completely so that he has no worries; give him the sort of food he likes ... and to work only for his good and the good of his career": Alf Ramsey, quoted in Leo McKinstry (2006) ''Sir Alf''.</ref> had once observed that he "didn't know much about women and the only women I know are footballers' wives". However, as his biographer noted, this remark was made "at a time when the phrase 'footballers' wives' had yet to become the embodiment of predatory lust."<ref name="Leo McKinstry 2006 Sir Alf"/>
Broadly speaking "Footballer's wife" and "WAG" were synonymous, but the latter was more generic, while the former connoted someone who seemed particularly pampered, perhaps with some of the characteristics also of an "[[Essex girl]]".
During the 2005–6 season the actress [[Joanna Taylor]], wife of Fulham midfielder [[Danny Murphy (footballer born 1977)|Danny Murphy]], wrote a regular column for the ''Times'' whose title, "Footballer's Wife", was no doubt partially ironic.
== "Jamelia" categorisation == Undoubtedly the "WAG" image of shopping and clubbing, as portrayed in the press in 2006, tended to stick. This led some WAGs, such as [[Girls Aloud]] member [[Cheryl Cole]], to reject the eponym and to emphasise their credentials as career women in their own right.<ref>London ''Evening Standard'', 5 July 2006</ref>
The singer [[Jamelia]] (whose footballer boyfriend, [[Darren Byfield]], played for [[Jamaica national football team|Jamaica]], which failed to qualify for the 2006 World Cup) drew a distinction between, on the one hand, those WAGs, such as Victoria Beckham, who are "businesswoman", and Cole and Rooney, who "have a job", and, on the other, those who, in her view, had the wrong "priorities" and simply spent their boyfriends' money.<ref>, such as [[Alex Curran]]''Metro'', 13 July 2</ref> This categorisation had some similarities both with Lisa Armstrong's comparison of supermodels with WAGs and with the suggested "WAG"/"footballers' wife" distinction. Indeed, it is possible to argue that, over the two-month period of 2006 that the WAGs were in the public spotlight, a subtle distinction emerged between "WAG" as a general acronym and the increasingly used "Wag" in the colloquial sense of a "footballer's wife".
==''WAGs Boutique''== In January 2007 a "reality" television series called ''[[WAGs Boutique]]'' ([[ITV2]]) was launched. This featured two teams of WAGs (few of whom had been among the party in Baden Baden the previous year) who competed to run fashion boutiques over a period of three months. The separation of one of the contenders, [[Michaela Henderson-Thynne]], from her erstwhile partner, [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] midfielder [[Stewart Downing]], raised some issues of principle and terminology. [[Giles Smith]] in the ''Times'' enquired whether "one can still be registered as a WAG after one has separated from one's footballer?"<ref>''The Times'', 1 March 2007</ref> Smith noted also that a former beauty queen and controversial ''[[Celebrity Big Brother (UK)|Celebrity Big Brother]]'' contestant, [[Danielle Lloyd]], whose relationship with [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]]'s [[Teddy Sheringham]] was "less than concrete", was referred to, during a guest appearance on ''WAGs Boutique'', as "an on-off WAG". Smith wondered whether, in those moments when a woman was an "off-WAG", she was really a WAG at all.<ref>''The Times'', 1 March 2007. ''Celebrity Big Brother'' was a "reality" game show on [[Channel 4]] television. In a series early in 2007 Daneille Lloyd, together with another contestant, [[Jade Goody]], had affronted some viewers with the language she used towards the eventual winner, the [[Bollywood]] actress [[Shilpa Shetty]].</ref> ''London Lite'' referred to Henderson-Thynne and [[Cassie Sumner]], a ''WAGs Boutique'' participant whose supposed relationship with [[Michael Essien]] was the subject of some doubt, as "fake WAGs".<ref>''London Lite'', 16 April 2007</ref>
==Spin-offs==
=== ''Les Wags'' and ''die WAGs'' === [[File:Girl Aloud 2.jpg|thumb|230px|[[Cheryl (entertainer)|Cheryl Cole]] (''née'' Tweedy), singer with [[Girls Aloud]]]] As if to emphasise the perceptive opinion of former England full-back [[Jimmy Armfield]] that there was "a real international flavour to this World Cup",<ref>BBC Radio 5 Live, quoted in ''Private Eye'', 23 June 2006</ref> the ''Sunday Times'' published during the 2006 tournament a photograph of the wives of French players [[Thierry Henry]] and [[David Trézéguet]] with the caption "French Wags Nicole Henry and Beatrice Trezeguet share a smacker [''i.e.'' kiss]".<ref>''Sunday Times'', 9 July 2006</ref>
For its part, the French press referred to the English wives and girlfriends (''"les épouses et petites amies des joueurs"'') as ''"les Wags"'': ''"Et lorsque les Wags ont fini leur shopping ..."'' [And when the Wags had finished their shopping].<ref>''Le Monde'', 26 June 2006</ref> Similarly, in German, ''"die WAGs"'' was adopted. Austria's ''Seitenblicke'', for example, carried a story ''"Ich bin keine WAG!"'' in German about Cheryl Cole's apparent disclaiming of the appellation of "WAG": ''"Ich war bei 'Girls Aloud' bevor ich Ashley [Cole] kennenlernte ..."'' [I was with Girls Aloud before I met Ashley].<ref>{{Cite web| url = http://www.seitenblicke.at/stars/starstories/artikel/4833/detail | title = Nennt mich ja nicht WAG! | coauthors = | date = 6 July 2006 | language=de | accessdate =2 February 2008 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060715110505/http://www.seitenblicke.at/stars/starstories/artikel/4833/detail | archivedate = 15 July 2006 | quote = Es nerve sie extrem, wenn die Leute sie als Fußballer-Frau bezeichnen, so Tweedy. "Ich war bei 'Girls Aloud' bevor ich Ashley kennlernte und hatte meine eigene erfolgreiche Karriere. Ich werde jetzt nicht die Band verlassen und den ganzen Tag in der Sonne rumsitzen oder mit Ashleys Kreditkarte shoppen gehen. Wenn ich shoppen gehe, dann mit meinem eigenen Geld, für das ich sehr hart gearbeitet habe." }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.seitenblicke.at/stars/starstories/artikel/4833/detail |title=Cheryl Cole lästert über Kicker-Frauen: "Nennt mich ja nicht WAG!" |publisher=Seitenblicke.at |accessdate=7 July 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060715110505/http://www.seitenblicke.at/stars/starstories/artikel/4833/detail |archivedate=15 July 2006 |df= }}</ref>
=== Father of the girlfriend of a footballer === When the father of Melanie Slade ([[Theo Walcott]]'s girlfriend), Councillor John Slade, was installed as Mayor of [[Southampton]], Hampshire on 17 May 2006, he was introduced by a fellow councillor, Alec Samuels, as "about the most famous mayor this city has had in 790 years ... He is the father of the girlfriend of a footballer".<ref>{{Cite web| url = http://www.24dash.com/content/news/viewNews.php?navID=2&newsID=5873 | title = New Southampton mayor sworn in – as Mel Slade's dad | publisher = 24dash.com | date = 17 May 2006 | first = Jon | last = Land | accessdate =7 July 2009 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070926231524/http://www.24dash.com/content/news/viewNews.php?navID=2&newsID=5873 | archivedate = 26 September 2007}}</ref>
===LA WAGs=== When it was announced in 2007 that David Beckham would be joining the American club [[Los Angeles Galaxy]], the ''Mail on Sunday'' referred to the "LA WAGs whose husbands earn less in ten years than Beckham in one week". The ''Mail'' claimed that these WAGs, who included actress [[Bianca Kajlich]], married to Beckham teammate [[Landon Donovan]], were "stay-at-home girls" who "possess not a [[Chloé]] dress, a [[Prada]] handbag or a [[Manolo Blahnik]] shoe between them. And they are awaiting the arrival of Victoria Beckham with some trepidation".<ref>''Mail on Sunday'', 14 January 2007</ref>
===Non-footballing WAGs===
====Lawn tennis==== During the course of the World Cup, the ''Times'' coined the term "WWAGs" ("[[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon]] Wives and Girlfriends") for the girlfriends of male participants in the All-England Lawn Tennis Championships in 2006.<ref name="Times, 3 July 2006"/> The most photographed WWAG in the British press during the tournament of 2006 was Kim Sears, the girlfriend of Scottish player [[Andy Murray]]. Sears is the daughter of Nigel Sears, former coach of the Slovak player [[Daniela Hantuchová]].
''The Sun'' used an alternative form, "WOWs" ("Wives of Wimbledon"), to draw attention to photographs of such "girls with WOW factor" as the Australian actress, [[Bec Hewitt]], ''née'' Cartwright, wife of [[Lleyton Hewitt]], Wimbledon champion in 2002.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Wheeler |first=Virginia |url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/article/0,,2-2006300613,00.html |title=Murray out of Wimbledon | The Sun |News |publisher=The Sun |date=4 July 2006 |accessdate=7 July 2009 |location=London}}</ref>
====Golf==== Interest in the private lives of golfers has been popular in the tabloids since the relationships of [[Nick Faldo]] and [[Tony Jacklin]], though not to the extent of footballers. Jacklin, who was then widowed at the time in 1988 had a date with a teenage girl, who then sold the story to ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' newspapers. Faldo is best remembered in the frontpage outside of sports, in 1998, having his [[Porsche 959]] trashed by an ex-girlfriend with his golf clubs. More recently, the marriage of [[Tiger Woods]] and [[Elin Nordegren]] received substantial media coverage; their marriage ended after even more widely publicised revelations of [[Tiger Woods#Infidelity scandal and fallout|Woods' serial infidelity]].
The term "wives and girlfriends" (in unabbreviated term) was commonly used during the [[Ryder Cup]] golfing competitions at [[The Belfry]] in [[2002 Ryder Cup|2002]] and [[Oakland Hills Country Club|Oakland Hills]] near Detroit in [[2004 Ryder Cup|2004]], the press having given these partners about as much coverage as the golfers themselves, due to the patriotic competitive nature of the sport which extends to themselves. ''[[London Lite]]''<ref>''London Lite'', 19 September 2006</ref> and ''[[Metro (Associated Metro Limited)|Metro]]''<ref>''Metro'', 20 September 2006</ref> used the slightly patronising acronym "WABs" ("wives and birdies", the latter a pun on the term for a one under [[par (score)|par]] score for a hole) with reference to the partners of the European team as they arrived in Ireland for the [[2006 Ryder Cup]] at [[The Kildare Hotel and Golf Club|The K Club]], Straffan, County Kildare. <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Jessica Taylor the CWAG.JPG|thumb|250px|left|[[Jessica Taylor (Liberty X)|Jessica Taylor]] the "CWAG" - headline in ''London Lite'', 27 November 2006]] -->
====Cricket==== "CWAGs" (Cricket Wives and Girlfriends) was applied to partners of the England [[cricket]] team in the series of [[Test cricket|test matches]] against Australia that began in [[Brisbane]], Queensland in November 2006: for example, "Jessica the Cwag knocks [[The Ashes|Ashes]] Test crowd for six"<ref>''London Lite'', 27 November 2006</ref> (the subject of this headline being singer [[Jessica Taylor (Liberty X)|Jessica Taylor]], of the group [[Liberty X]], fiancée of batsman and occasional [[off-spin]]ner [[Kevin Pietersen]]). Although "CWAG" (rather than "WAG") was not used all that widely, there were predictable claims after England had lost the series 5–0 that the presence of wives and girlfriends had undermined the cohesion of the touring party.<ref>''Mail on Sunday'', 7 January 2007</ref> "WAG" had previously been applied in the context of cricket: for example to model [[Minki van der Westhuizen]], who had been associated with the South African captain, [[Graeme Smith]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cricket.mailliw.com/archives/2006/11/01/slinki-minki-the-fans-favourite-wag/ |title=Slinky Minki the fans’ favourite WAG | The Corridor (a cricket blog) |publisher=Cricket.mailliw.com |accessdate=7 July 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090627174214/http://www.cricket.mailliw.com/archives/2006/11/01/slinki-minki-the-fans-favourite-wag/ |archivedate=27 June 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
More recently, the Australian media has started to use the "WAG" term to describe the partners of [[Australian cricket team|their own cricket team]]. See [[Australian Cricket WAGs]].
====British Royal Family==== In July 2006 ''The Sun'' carried an article on the "RAGs" ("Royals and Girlfriends"), a term introduced for young female members of the British Royal Family, as well as [[Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge|Kate Middleton]], then girlfriend and now [[Wedding of Prince William and Catherine Middleton|wife]] of [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge|Prince William]], and [[Chelsy Davy]], then girlfriend of [[Prince Harry]].<ref>''The Sun'', 3 July 2006</ref> Others identified as "RAGs" were [[Princess Beatrice of York|Princess Beatrice]], [[Princess Eugenie of York|Princess Eugenie]], champion equestrian [[eventing|eventer]] [[Zara Phillips]], and [[Lady Gabriella Windsor]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/article/0,,2001290023-2006300524_1,00.html |title=The Best for News, Sport, Showbiz, Celebrities & TV |publisher=The Sun |accessdate=7 July 2009 |location=London }} {{Dead link|date=April 2014|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref> Subsequently, under the heading "Windsor Mads outdo the Wags", Jasper Gerard reported in the ''Sunday Times'' on festivities involving "the Windsor Mads (mothers and daughters), as [[Sarah, Duchess of York|Fergie]] [Sarah, Duchess of York] and Eugenie celebrated Beatrice's forthcoming 18th birthday".<ref>''Sunday Times'', 16 July 2006</ref>
====Motor racing==== Though the term has never been used, many high-profile sportsmen in motor racing have publicly enjoyed high-profile relationships with celebrities, for instance [[Jacques Villeneuve]]'s relationship with [[Dannii Minogue]] and the former marriage of [[Dario Franchitti]] and [[Ashley Judd]].
One example of a well known wife of a sportsman is Michaela Fogarty, the wife of former [[Superbike World Championship]] star [[Carl Fogarty|Carl]]. At the height of her husband's fame, she has been photographed in pit and paddock areas and has also appeared in print advertisements for [[Ducati]] motorcycles, which her husband has ridden for. Despite never appearing in the spotlight, much of her popularity is within the motorcycling fraternity, as she is known for her support of her husband. The two have even appeared in a series which they embark on an adventure riding.
====Rugby League==== Many partners of [[Rugby League]] players are increasingly being associated with the WAGs term by the media. Examples include [[Terry Biviano]], [[Candice Falzon]] and [[Lauryn Eagle]]
====Rugby Union==== Many partners of [[Rugby Union]] players are increasingly being associated with the WAGs term by the media. Examples include [[The Saturdays]] singer [[Una Healy]] who is married to English rugby player [[Ben Foden]] and actress [[Susie Amy]] who is in a relationship with Irish rugby player [[Rob Kearney]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2035879/Meet-Rugby-World-Cup-WAGS-theyre-just-pretty-faces.html|title=Meet the Rugby World Cup WAGs (but they're not just pretty faces)|work=Daily Mail|accessdate=26 December 2013|location=London|first=Alanah|last=Eriksen|date=10 September 2011}}</ref> The British [[Equestrianism|equestrian]] and grandchild of [[Queen Elizabeth II]] [[Zara Phillips]] has been labelled a WAG for her marriage to English [[centre (rugby union)|centre]] [[Mike Tindall]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-2292666/Cheltenham-Festival-2013-Zara-rugby-WAGs-enjoy-giggly-Ladies-Day.html|title=Zara and rugby WAGs enjoy a giggly Ladies' Day at Cheltenham|work=Daily mail|accessdate=26 December 2013|location=London|first=Louise|last=Eccles|date=13 March 2013}}</ref>
New Zealand [[field hockey]] player [[Honor Dillon]] has been called a WAG since her marriage to [[out half (rugby union)|out-half]] [[Dan Carter]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/rugbyunion/2319439/All-Blacks-ban-Wags-from-players-rooms.html|title=All Blacks ban Wags from players' rooms|work=telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=26 December 2013|location=London|first1=Andy|last1=Hooper|date=20 August 2007}}</ref> Irish model [[Holly Carpenter]] also has the WAG title from the press due to being the girlfriend of [[Cian Healy]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/woman/celeb-news/jersey-pullers-on-the-hunt-for-stray-players-29471129.html|title=Jersey pullers on the hunt for stray players|work=independent.ie|accessdate=26 December 2013|date=4 August 2013}}</ref>
====Shinty====
The traditional Scottish sport of [[shinty]] has developed the terminology "SWAGs" to refer to the wives and partners of shinty players. The terms was given further credence by an hour long documentary on [[BBC Alba]], following various partners throughout a shinty season.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b03m7826] Some of the "SWAGs" featured in the programme have been given further prominence in print [http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/real-life/tv-show-follows-life-touchline-2648890] and at shinty events.[http://www.skyecamanachd.com/news/SWAGs-To-Make-2014-Shinty-Cup-Draws.htm]
=== Other acronyms === Other imitative acronyms to emerge in 2006 included:
{| class="wikitable" |- !Acronyms !Description |- |CHAPs |"celebrities' husbands and partners";<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/showbiz/tm_objectid=17400831&method=full&siteid=94762&headline=chap-awards--name_page.html |title=Chap Awards |work=Daily Mirror |location=UK |date=18 July 2006 |accessdate=7 July 2009}}</ref> |- |HABs |"husbands and boyfriends" for the partners of female tennis players at Wimbledon (and other female athletes);<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://thescotsman.scotsman.com/sport.cfm?id=971752006 |title=The Scotsman |publisher=Thescotsman.scotsman.com |date=13 January 2009 |accessdate=7 July 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016220215/http://thescotsman.scotsman.com/sport.cfm?id=971752006 |archivedate=16 October 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> |- |MAGs |"mothers and girlfriends", or the singular "MAG" for mother of a WAG (''e.g.'' "Wonder who's paying for Coleen's MAG's shopping?"<ref>''London Lite'', 20 October 2006</ref>) |- |SADs |"sons and daughters" of footballers, a term used by the ''Sunday Times'' with reference to Bianca Gascoigne, daughter of [[Paul Gascoigne]] who played for England in the 1990 World Cup, [[Shaun Wright-Phillips]], the adopted son of [[Ian Wright]] (Arsenal and England) and [[Calum Best]], son of [[George Best]] (Manchester United & Northern Ireland);<ref name="Sunday Times, 3 September 2006"/> |- |SWAGs |used both for "supporters without a game" (''e.g.'' England fans at a loose end in Germany on days when their team was not playing<ref>{{Cite web|last=Gripper |first=Ann |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/worldcup/news/tm_objectid=17307747&method=full&siteid=94762&headline=nothing-to-do-but-look-at-the-wags-name_page.html |title=Nothing To Do But Look At The Wags |work=Daily Mirror |location=UK |date=29 June 2006 |accessdate=7 July 2009}}</ref>) and, according to the ''Guardian'', "Summit wives and girlfriends" (the partners of World leaders attending the [[G8]] [[32nd G8 summit|Summit]] in [[Saint Petersburg|St Petersburg]], Russia on 15–17 July 2006).<ref>''Guardian'', 18 July 2006</ref> |}
==== ''Private Eye'' ==== In an irreverent parody – "Those World Cup Acronyms in Full" – the satirical magazine ''[[Private Eye]]'' (which had, among other things, imagined a table-top game, with a [[Gucci]] ball, called "[[Subbuteo]] Footballers' Wives" and referred to Coleen (McLoughlin) Rooney as "Noleen McCleavage"<ref>''The Private Eye Annual 2006'' (ed [[Ian Hislop]])</ref>) offered such additional terms as "SHAGS" ("unofficial girlfriends whose numbers appear on footballers' mobile phones") and "GAGS" ("Writs served by footballers accused of relationships with SHAGS").<ref>''Private Eye'', 7 July 2006</ref> Both of these were allusions to rumours two years earlier about the private life of an England international player.
Following the weddings of four England players in a single weekend in 2007, the ''Eye'''s "[[Glenda Slagg]]" column referred jokingly to "SLAGS": "that's 'Stupid Lazy and Grasping Slappers' – Geddit?!?".<ref>''Private Eye'', 22 June – 5 July 2007</ref>
==Criticism== In an October 2008 press conference, England and Manchester United footballer [[Rio Ferdinand]] heavily criticised the WAGS culture, particularly in Baden-Baden two years previously, calling it a "circus" and giving praise to new England manager [[Fabio Capello]]'s more disciplined regime,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/internationals/wags-circus-era-ridiculed-by-ferdinand-961253.html |title='WAGs circus' era ridiculed by Ferdinand – International, Football |work=The Independent |location=London |date=15 October 2008 |accessdate=7 July 2009 | first=Jason | last=Burt}}</ref> and after England had qualified for the [[2010 World Cup]] by beating [[Croatia]] 5–1, Capello made his first public comment on the WAGs by making it clear that the England players will only be able to see their wives and partners the day after a match, stating that "We are there to play, not for a holiday".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/internationals/capello-leave-the-wags-at-home-this-time.1785298.html |title=Capello-Leave the WAGs at home this time – International, Football |work=The Independent |location=London |date=11 September 2009 |accessdate=12 September 2009 | first=Sam | last=Wallace}}</ref> As it happened, the England team were knocked out of that tournament at an even earlier stage.
==In popular culture== In the [[Estelle (musician)|Estelle]] song "[[American Boy (Estelle song)|American Boy]]", [[Kanye West]] [[rap music|rap]]s the lyrics; "But I still talk that ca-a-sh, Cuz a lotta WAGS wanna hear it".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/a81326/kanye-west-to-rap-about-wags-on-new-song.html |title=Kanye West to rap about WAGs on new song |work=Digital Spy |accessdate=7 July 2009}}</ref> Two novels have been published about WAGs. The first, ''A Wag's Diary'', was released in October 2007, published by Harper Collins; the second, ''A Wag's Diary in LA'', was published in June 2008. Both books are written by [[Alison Kervin]].
A 2015 American [[reality television]] series titled ''[[WAGS (TV series)|WAGS]]'' aired on the [[E!|E! network]], featuring both the professional and personal lives of several WAGs. Two spin-off series, ''[[WAGS Miami]]'' and ''[[WAGS Atlanta]]'', were also produced, focusing on WAGs in [[Miami]] and [[Atlanta]], respectively. [[VH1]]'s ''[[Basketball Wives]]'' and its various spin-offs have also featured the concept, instead involving the significant others of [[professional basketball]] players.

revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category Hearst Corporation to [[:Category:Hearst Communications]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
{{orphan|date = April 2011}} {{Italic title}} '''''Wandt v. Hearst's Chicago American''''' (1906) 129 Wis. 419, 109 NW 70
The ''[[Chicago American]]'' ran a picture next to an article about a person who repeatedly attempted to [[commit suicide]]. Although it wasn't explicit that the picture was of that person, the location of the picture next to that article created a false association that constituted [[libel]]. This case is authority that: where a person's picture is taken by a [[photographer]], there is a breach of an [[implied contract]] or relationship of [[trust (social sciences)|trust]] when the photographer makes additional pictures and uses them for commercial purposes.<ref>http://epublications.marquette.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=4161&context=mulr</ref>
